[Robert Penta]: My name is Robert Penta, Zero Summit Road, Medford, Mass.

[Robert Penta]: Having served on this board some years ago, the city of Medford and Tufts University engaged in the pilot, a million dollar pilot program.

[Robert Penta]: And the pilot program consisted of six students from Medford, six students from Somerville, who'd be able to go to Tufts University for nothing.

[Robert Penta]: The million dollar cash part of the program consisted of three years of getting cash up front with the remaining portions of the money to be used for

[Robert Penta]: Now that hasn't been followed through since, for what reason, I don't know.

[Robert Penta]: But speaking with leaders up at the State House, the one thing that the City of Medford hasn't done, as other cities and towns done, you have not moved to provide an amendment to the CPA tax, which would include affordable housing.

[Robert Penta]: And as a result of that, and knowing that the Commonwealth now does not give back to the City of Medford from their surplus to the CPA, it's all going to be on cities and towns, excuse me, individually.

[Robert Penta]: You know, you give it to churches, you've given it to schools into swimming pools and open space and land.

[Robert Penta]: And by amending it to put this inclusion in there, this will be your first step along with your 25% for the purpose of going forward to get your affordable housing.

[Robert Penta]: She bought a house for $44,000, then she paid 68,000.

[Robert Penta]: She was the American dream.

[Robert Penta]: And why should she be penalized in her senior years of her senior American dream that she would have that money that she would have to give back that's not going to her.

[Robert Penta]: You know, we're talking about a democracy each and every day with this political election that's coming up.

[Robert Penta]: Right now, what you folks are talking about, socialism.

[Robert Penta]: You think you should be sharing your people's products.

[Robert Penta]: It's wrong to get in this mode.

[Robert Penta]: My name is Robert Penta, Zero Summit Road, Method Mass, former member of this August body.

[Robert Penta]: First of all, let me start by saying, what does this pay raise have to do with education?

[Robert Penta]: That's number one.

[Robert Penta]: Number two, there's no demanding from the public for any pay raise for the school committee.

[Robert Penta]: And lastly, there's no professional city population job description pay report that even substantiates or supports what the council has alluded to.

[Robert Penta]: Fire, police, school teachers, they all have different job duties and responsibilities.

[Robert Penta]: My name is Robert Penta, Zero Summit Road, Medford, Mass., a former member of this August party on the City Council.

[Robert Penta]: Massachusetts General Laws, Chapter 71, Section 52, does grant to the City Council, by a majority vote and by the city charter, the responsibility of how much members of the school committee get paid.

[Robert Penta]: But historically, the city council has paid more than the city school committee because the council's responsibilities exceed those of the school committee.

[Robert Penta]: The city council responsibilities include, but are not limited to enacting ordinances, zoning, fire and police, public safety requirements, setting the city's tax rate, and has the final authority over the city and school department budget.

[Robert Penta]: As examples of major differences between one challenging equal pay for equal work between the city council and the school committee.

[Robert Penta]: Further, just as in any business, job responsibilities and pay are what one is applying for.

[Robert Penta]: Under this proposal, it is a gender attack being disguised as pay parity, for equal pay for equal work, for which it is not.

[Robert Penta]: The proposed school department 100% plus pay increase will be paid from the Medford Public Schools.

[Robert Penta]: Let's take a look at what that means.

[Robert Penta]: Annually, we are barely able to meet the resources we have now at our school's disposal.

[Robert Penta]: We've sat here for years with former Councilors and myself, and we never, never experienced anything that was presented in the middle of the night.

[Robert Penta]: That's what July is, it's the heat of the night, it's hot out, it's almost 90 degrees.

[Robert Penta]: where the people that this hall should be full of people.

[Robert Penta]: And it's not because as Councilman alluded to, there was an issue way back a couple of two or three years ago in Mystic Avenue in the month of August when they had a public hearing and all the people showed up and they got so scared as to what's going on, they canceled the meeting.

[Robert Penta]: And after they canceled the meeting, they took the vote.

[Robert Penta]: No way should this happen.

[Robert Penta]: Let me just leave you with this last thing.

[Robert Penta]: Your own Rule 19 on the Medford City Council states that the Medford City Council shall not approve of any bond or expenditure that does not have a written explanation of such expenditure at least seven days prior to said vote.

[Robert Penta]: You got this three to four days prior to today.

[Robert Penta]: That's not seven days.

[Robert Penta]: And your own rules also state

[Robert Penta]: We've gone through the years, situations,

[Robert Penta]: No matter what the outcome is with the investigation, which is now criminal, that in and of itself ought to tell you something's going on, and I hope our police department, and I hope our police department does find it out.

[Robert Penta]: You know, everybody tonight has kept mentioning, you know, the mayor's comments.

[Robert Penta]: The mayor's comments were written on

[Robert Penta]: July 17th regarding the July 15th rally.

[Robert Penta]: Because they stood there in behalf of, they stood there, they didn't even speak, they stood there in behalf of our Metro Police Department.

[Robert Penta]: The people are right there every day defending us and taking care of the needs of our community.

[Robert Penta]: Why would you want to turn a blind eye to that?

[Robert Penta]: That's ridiculous.

[Robert Penta]: Fire department, school department, teachers, first responders.

[Robert Penta]: This is wrong what's going on in this city.

[Robert Penta]: And you'll never see the right time of day.

[Robert Penta]: My name is Robert Penta, Zero Summit Road, former member of the circus party.

[Robert Penta]: I'd like to read a three-page prepared commentary

[Robert Penta]: that I find and feel to be very important.

[Robert Penta]: It's a message from Memorial Day to Flag Day, and it's a commentary to our Medford residents.

[Robert Penta]: Memorial Day, why is my speakers off?

[Robert Penta]: Memorial Day was never intended as a celebration to remind us of the ugliness and the ravages of war, but rather to honor in some solemn observance, our men and women,

[Robert Penta]: their survivors, and our allied comrades who sacrificed their lives to protect our liberty and our freedoms here at home and around the world.

[Robert Penta]: Likewise, our Flag Day observance on June 14th is but an annual reminder of some 244 years ago when the Second Continental Congress, along with George Washington, took a break from their writing of the Articles of Confederation to establish a standard bearer

[Robert Penta]: to be the unifying symbol of our colonial fighting forces and for our freedom.

[Robert Penta]: As our fledgling nation was moving forward in its quest for its independence, that is how Old Glory was commissioned to be our American flag.

[Robert Penta]: From Memorial Day remembrances of lives given up to protect our America, to the flag day birth of old glory, both symbolizing the embodiment of our right of free speech, we are here today.

[Robert Penta]: But in the interim of many years, what has happened to our country, state, and local cities and towns nationwide, especially over the past 30 years in particular?

[Robert Penta]: When the politically correct crowd of progressives and liberals began complaining that our public displays of patriotism is offensive to others, and we have to back off such displays, and that we are a systematically racist country as well as a city, and that we need to practice cancel culture, wokeness, defund the police, teach systematic race theory, and being a white supremacist,

[Robert Penta]: and accept revisionary history as history's new truth, I take offense to such broad universal commentaries, especially by Washington politicians and self-serving proclaimed educators who have made their living by espousing race as their financial and social calling card for more than the past 20 years.

[Robert Penta]: With crime running at an all time high, illegal immigration crossing our borders, causing ongoing social welfare, educational, security, and uncontrollable medical problems, we have now become the victims of today's liberal and progressives agenda of inclusion without requirement or responsibility.

[Robert Penta]: Also, if God offends anyone, then I suggest you consider another part of the world as your new home, because our good God is part of our American inheritance of religious freedoms secure from governmental intervention.

[Robert Penta]: And if our American stars and stripes offend you, or you do not like or believe in our Uncle Sam, and you don't have the tolerance for free speech, then you should seriously consider exporting yourself to another country.

[Robert Penta]: In conclusion,

[Robert Penta]: Our First Amendment gives every citizen the right to express his or her opinion.

[Robert Penta]: But for those who complain, whine, or gripe, or dislike our American way of life, as well as our city of Medford way of life, don't let the door slam you as you leave, because you do have the right and the opportunity to leave.

[Robert Penta]: We are not a perfect society.

[Robert Penta]: but there is no other country that offers more freedoms than our America.

[Robert Penta]: So from a Memorial Day remembrance to a Flag Day observation, let not our freedom of thought, speech, and expression ever be challenged by some ideology that bears no fruit but hatred, division, and racism.

[Robert Penta]: Thank you and let our method never be a part of any such movement or agenda.

[Robert Penta]: I felt Mr. President and Councilors, I had to say that because after being at the Memorial Day service and listening to our veterans director emotionally present before our community that for which a veteran is all about.

[Robert Penta]: I feel as an American.

[Robert Penta]: I am a white Italian American.

[Robert Penta]: I'm proud of it.

[Robert Penta]: I am not a racist, and I don't intend to be a racist.

[Robert Penta]: I encompass anyone and everyone who wishes to express their opinion, and I would hope that our city of Medford does not go down any path that disrespects the fact of who we are as individuals.

[Robert Penta]: It should be removed.

[Robert Penta]: Mr. President, I'm Bob Pento, Zero Summit Road, Method Mass.

[Robert Penta]: Robert Penta, Zero Summit Road.

[Robert Penta]: I want to go back to the December of 2002.

[Robert Penta]: And at that point in time, there was a gentleman by the name of Donald Ouellette, who became the city engineer here in the city of Medford.

[Robert Penta]: And one of the reasons why he became the new city engineer is because he came from the community of Air Mass, where he instituted a new water metering program.

[Robert Penta]: At the time, Paul Guia was our director of public works.

[Robert Penta]: And in December of 2002,

[Robert Penta]: Mr. Roulette came on board.

[Robert Penta]: In January 20th of 2003, Councilor Marks and myself at the time were interviewed by the local newspaper for the purposes of the concerns that were out in the neighborhood regarding the water meter and the bills that were going on.

[Robert Penta]: And at that point in time, information came forward that for the past three years, prior to 2003, there were over 709 abatements

[Robert Penta]: that were issued by the city of Medford because of faulty water meters.

[Robert Penta]: Mr. Roulette, when he came in, indicated that the city of Medford's water meters at that time were no more, they should be no more than 10 years of age.

[Robert Penta]: They were 17 years old at the time.

[Robert Penta]: So that began the crusade, so to speak, of figuring out how are we going to change these water meters?

[Robert Penta]: Should we change these water meters?

[Robert Penta]: And when are we going to do it?

[Robert Penta]: At the time, there was over 15,000 households that had water meters that needed to be changed, as well as 150 large capacity commercial district people, which represented 50% of the water consumption and the use at that time.

[Robert Penta]: Now, in August of 2003, the concerns kept multiplying on the council from residents complaining about their tax bills.

[Robert Penta]: And October 23rd, in a very rare moment by former Mayor McGlynn, he acknowledged at a public meeting that it was his fault that the meters were not changed.

[Robert Penta]: And the reason is the concern wasn't as bad as it was.

[Robert Penta]: And he told the Water and Soil Commission at that point in time that blame me, that was his quote, blame me because they just didn't want to get into the financial obligation of getting into the water meters, not realizing how serious everything was.

[Robert Penta]: And that's okay.

[Robert Penta]: because that got itself corrected after that.

[Robert Penta]: Then on February 17 of 2004, Mayor McGlynn presented before the city council a prelude, a prelude so to speak as to what the water meter sewer count should look like and what do we need to do here to go in the city of Medford.

[Robert Penta]: But what he did and what he proposed, which was kind of interesting, he proposed to finance $18,000

[Robert Penta]: have the city council vote for $18,000 to do a preliminary review on X amount of homes and X amount of businesses in the city, just to see how bad these water meters were in commercial meters.

[Robert Penta]: And what they found out was an atrocious, the decision or the results were atrocious, because what came out of all of that, where these meters were running much slower, and as a result of them running much slower, the city was losing a tremendous amount of revenue.

[Robert Penta]: So in October of 2004,

[Robert Penta]: straight down October 19th, the city council voted the appropriation for $4.2 million to put new water meters here in the city of Medford.

[Robert Penta]: And subsequent to that, the chase goes on.

[Robert Penta]: At that point in time, and that's back in 2003, at the end of 2003, the city of Medford was losing on a daily basis 189 million gallons of water a day, not getting billed, and their leakage was 113 million gallons a day.

[Robert Penta]: Those two numbers, and I would hope somebody in the council would pick up on that and make a request as to what our leakage is and loss of revenue from then it is now.

[Robert Penta]: The new water meters that came in, once again, had a 10 year lifespan and the meters on this new meeting system, they had batteries in their battery life, according to their own information that they passed up as a 10 year life.

[Robert Penta]: We've well exceeded a 10 year life on these batteries.

[Robert Penta]: The mic isn't.

[Robert Penta]: Bob Penta, Zero Summit Road, Medford, Mass.

[Robert Penta]: Mr. President, I appreciate the fact that this is an ongoing thing, and I want to compliment Councilor Marks

[Robert Penta]: because speaking throughout the community, he has taken the charge on this particular issue, not to be for or against, but just to bring the awareness and to have some understanding of a communication.

[Robert Penta]: As I said before, this is a $5 billion G5 undertaking by Verizon.

[Robert Penta]: And some two years ago, when they first came into the city and had a discussion on this, they allegedly stated there was 143 locations or 143 polls

[Robert Penta]: that they had identified here in the city of Medford as to where they were gonna go.

[Robert Penta]: Now, these poles are all owned by National Grid and on National Grid's poles, you have fire, you have police, you have alarm systems.

[Robert Penta]: They're all pole renters and they pay National Grid to be on those poles.

[Robert Penta]: And by paying National Grid to be on those poles, National Grid is now receiving a financial inducement, so to speak.

[Robert Penta]: In return, that inducement doesn't find itself anywhere back to the rate payers of National Grid, but all Verizon is doing is getting more and more profit.

[Robert Penta]: And they're not spending $5 billion just for the sake of having $5 billion to spend, because the subscribers to Verizon plans are gonna pay for that in the long run.

[Robert Penta]: There's been no explanation as between 4G to 5G, whether there's anything medically or substantially different,

[Robert Penta]: that could possibly hurt somebody because of the medical portions of that.

[Robert Penta]: So the question then becomes, and alluding back to council Marx's comment, if you have the lady who is a board of health director, who sits on this board of four, which makes no sense at all, but who sits on this board of four, you've had 11 votes so far.

[Robert Penta]: And of those 11 votes, six of them have been against and five of them had been for.

[Robert Penta]: Now, I would strongly suggest that you would ask, some one of you folks, ask a question of why the people voted the way they did.

[Robert Penta]: Because if you understood last week, there was two young ladies here from a certain part of Medford who was concerned about a poll being in front of their house and the poll being in front of their house, not wanting it there, not knowing what the 5G could admit.

[Robert Penta]: So of the five that got approved as compared to the six that didn't get approved,

[Robert Penta]: Do the six have an argument against the five or does the five have an argument against the six?

[Robert Penta]: Are we going to play what kind of game is this going to turn out to be?

[Robert Penta]: Who gets it and who doesn't get it?

[Robert Penta]: It's not right.

[Robert Penta]: But the most important thing that I think is missing here that the mayor of this community, having this committee being sent up should have made some kind of an agreement with Verizon as to what the city of Medford is going to get in return

[Robert Penta]: for having Verizon come into this city and go from 4G to 5G, because the only one right now that's going to be making all the money up front is going to be National Grid on the poles.

[Robert Penta]: And Verizon in the long run will get this, whether it goes to 5G, 6G, 7G, who knows, that's not the point.

[Robert Penta]: The fact of the matter is they're here, they were planning for it as of two years ago, whether it's 143 poles or 143 locations, that seems to be the issue.

[Robert Penta]: So if you're going to have this meeting,

[Robert Penta]: this meeting, however this meeting is going to be sent up, what's the logic?

[Robert Penta]: What's the reasoning behind approval and disapproval?

[Robert Penta]: And if the director of public health voted against it, and even if it was because she felt that it wasn't right for the city, then it's not right for the city all the time, not just part of the time.

[Robert Penta]: And those people that voted for it, as compared to the six times they didn't vote for it, well, what was their logic to it?

[Robert Penta]: And I think it's very important that if they're going to make a decision, and you said there's 11 requirements on there, then those 11 requirements have to be met by all applicants that come, all 42 applicants.

[Robert Penta]: So if that's being said, there's no logic, there's no rhyme or reason right now to the 11 decisions that have been made thus far, six for, six against, and five for.

[Robert Penta]: How do you justify that?

[Robert Penta]: How do you explain to the city that you have this committee of ongoing people with no experts on there

[Robert Penta]: That doesn't make any sense at all.

[Robert Penta]: And when the taxpayers can ask that question, you have this subcommittee that's not even odd number, it's even.

[Robert Penta]: and you're being restricted according to FCC that you can't vote because of any medical concerns, but you have your own director of public health on the committee and she votes against it.

[Robert Penta]: Well, what's her logic for voting against it?

[Robert Penta]: What are all the other members who voted against it?

[Robert Penta]: What was their logic?

[Robert Penta]: And what was the logic of the five that got approved?

[Robert Penta]: My name is Robert Penta, Zero Summit Road.

[Robert Penta]: I don't know if you can hear me.

[Robert Penta]: No, can you hear it?

[Robert Penta]: Back in May of 2017, what was presented here before the city of Medford was a new, what they call a base,

[Robert Penta]: rate of 861 per household.

[Robert Penta]: And then the different charge would be for the commercial district folks here in the city of Medford.

[Robert Penta]: And then one of the arguments was that it would raise $1 million a year.

[Robert Penta]: That was approximately 4% of what the city's budget was at that point in time required for the water and sewer services in the city of Medford.

[Robert Penta]: Subsequent to that, it's gone on for the last three years.

[Robert Penta]: now coming into its fourth fiscal year.

[Robert Penta]: And I believe a response that was sent back to the city, you folks, pursuant to a request from one of your colleagues, was a breakdown of how much money each and every one of the last three fiscal years amounted to.

[Robert Penta]: Inclusive of that amount, again, was the term of $1 million to be used per year, but they never reached the $1 million per year.

[Robert Penta]: What was reached was $2,585,362.66 as compared to the $3 million that was allegedly stated that the city would gain.

[Robert Penta]: That's a difference of $414,637.

[Robert Penta]: So where do we go with that?

[Robert Penta]: Where we go with that, the argument was that that would be used to supplement water and sewer for whatever needs might be if something were to come up

[Robert Penta]: also to subsidize the water and sewer department in case of something that's anticipated.

[Robert Penta]: In the letter that came back, it indicated here that the universal connectivity fee is an infrastructure recovery charge to be hooked into and maintained in the water and sewer system.

[Robert Penta]: The fixed base connectivity fee is estimated at $1 million per year to help stabilize revenues in this place.

[Robert Penta]: That response also indicated that that money goes to your water and sewer account.

[Robert Penta]: There is no breakdown.

[Robert Penta]: There is no breakdown to the charges, commercial or residential.

[Robert Penta]: There is no breakdown also as to how and where that money has been spent.

[Robert Penta]: And there is no program that is set up presently that tells you what that money can be used for.

[Robert Penta]: So right now, all it's done has been included into your water and sewer account.

[Robert Penta]: One of the misnomers to this whole project, when sold back in 2017, was in case there is a, in case, that's the word, in case there is a deficit in either the water or sewer account.

[Robert Penta]: In the years 2016 and 17, there were deficits on the sewer side, not the water side.

[Robert Penta]: But each and every year, when the water and sewer budget is estimated, it's estimated on what the work is going to be here in the city of Medford, and also,

[Robert Penta]: The water and the sewer rates that you get from the MWRA, those rates come in ahead of time, not after a budget is made and set.

[Robert Penta]: That's another misnomer as it relates to the full program.

[Robert Penta]: So approximately right now, you're sitting on $2,585,000 of base rate fees or charges, whatever the term you want to use, that has come from the Mr. and Mrs. Metro taxpayer has been put into the general revenues of your water and sewer account.

[Robert Penta]: That ladies and gentlemen is not the proper accounting practices and procedures because in your own water and sewer account, you have to have it broken down.

[Robert Penta]: You have it broken down by employees.

[Robert Penta]: You have it broken down by cost of material.

[Robert Penta]: You have it broken down by the named individuals in the trucks and everything else that goes along with it.

[Robert Penta]: My suggestion to you folks would be simply this.

[Robert Penta]: You can't put a fee on somebody or a charge

[Robert Penta]: without knowing what you're charging them for.

[Robert Penta]: It's not fair.

[Robert Penta]: If that's the case, you should have just raised the water and sewer account by the approximate 4% that you think it was going to do to offset it.

[Robert Penta]: So if you're sitting on a surplus of approximately $7 million or thereabouts in your water and sewer enterprise account, and you're sitting on approximately having already raised $2.5 million, but you still don't know how it was spent, where it was gonna go,

[Robert Penta]: Where is the projected projects that are supposed to come?

[Robert Penta]: It doesn't make any sense because right now, what it's saying is it's a water and sewage charge.

[Robert Penta]: It was to services in case something were to happen.

[Robert Penta]: The original proposal back in 2017 was the charge for the water meeting.

[Robert Penta]: And that was the charge that was going to be placed on each and every residential person.

[Robert Penta]: So we know right now that that charge every single time, once it comes out,

[Robert Penta]: is not for the meter.

[Robert Penta]: But unfortunately, for accounting purposes, because you can't figure it out, in this city, in the accounting department, there is nothing to be found that'll tell you how and where that money was spent.

[Robert Penta]: But you can find it in water and sewer, in their particular budgets, independently separated.

[Robert Penta]: My suggestion would be to you, that you have a budget coming up this year.

[Robert Penta]: I would hope that maybe somebody would make a request and ask the question, because it doesn't make any sense

[Robert Penta]: that the response that came back from the finance director, we don't keep an accounting.

[Robert Penta]: Well, if you don't keep an accounting, how do you keep an accounting of residential and commercial meters that you have and what you're going to be charged?

[Robert Penta]: How can you allege that you're going to be taking in a million dollars a year when you haven't even got to that figure?

[Robert Penta]: Something needs to be said as it relates to these type of budgetary items.

[Robert Penta]: Seven weeks ago, I came in here and I think I explained something like seven items.

[Robert Penta]: I'm going to go through them all one at a time, not tonight, Mr. President.

[Robert Penta]: I will go through them all one at a time.

[Robert Penta]: Because good accounting procedures tells you what comes in has got to go out and how does it go out.

[Robert Penta]: You've got situations here that you really don't know why should you be charging these people to supplement or augment a water and sewer account that's presently sitting in millions of dollars.

[Robert Penta]: You have yet to be told what the cost is going to be for an anticipated construction

[Robert Penta]: sidewalk, street reconstruction might be because of water and sewer.

[Robert Penta]: So if you keep taking in these monies from Mr. and Mrs. Taxpayer, you're overcharging them.

[Robert Penta]: You're overcharging them each and every year on this base rate, the speed, whatever it might be.

[Robert Penta]: Point of information, Mr. President.

[Robert Penta]: Well, while that may be true, there's also, you talk about general accounting practices.

[Robert Penta]: General accounting practices does state that if you are going to put a budgetary item on a budget, as you councilors get each and every year, the question needs to be asked, if I'm going to just put $100 million, so to speak, and put it into a line item, and there's no accounting of the money, other than the fact I just put it into an account, what's the purpose of that?

[Robert Penta]: So you're right, it's an administrative prerogative, but when it came up in May of 2017, it was contentiously argued at this Medford City Council as to why we need this new fee.

[Robert Penta]: And at that point in time, the argument was for the purposes of the meters, for the accounting of the meters.

[Robert Penta]: Now it's going into the general revenue, and now we're being told that there is no delineation, there's no explanation, there's no accounting of how that money's being spent.

[Robert Penta]: So if that's the case,

[Robert Penta]: And as Councilors, if there's no explanation of how it's being spent, before you used to have the accounting firm of Melanson and Heath, you don't have them anymore.

[Robert Penta]: You have them for like 15 years out of New Hampshire.

[Robert Penta]: You have a new accounting company that comes in here, they're supposed to do an annual audit.

[Robert Penta]: That question ought to come up.

[Robert Penta]: Because if you remember correctly, if you looked at the Melanson and Heath audits, that was one of their concerns on the MWRA, especially in our water and sewer accounts, if you go back and read them, the accounting and the prioritizing how the money is spent.

[Robert Penta]: This account, or this money, Councilor Knight, there's no accounting with the money.

[Robert Penta]: It just goes into a general revenue.

[Robert Penta]: As watchdogs of the city's money, over and beyond the administration, the administration can make a proposal.

[Robert Penta]: The bottom line is here with the council.

[Robert Penta]: You either vote it up or you vote it down.

[Robert Penta]: And if you're going to vote it up or you're going to vote it down,

[Robert Penta]: The question is, what are you voting on?

[Robert Penta]: Then I would respectfully suggest, if we follow that train of thought, I would respectfully suggest a freedom of information

[Robert Penta]: request to the city auditor, asking the city auditor.

[Robert Penta]: As to why, Mr. President, why there is no accounting.

[Robert Penta]: When you get the money from the MWRA ahead of time, before a budget is made, there's an accounting of how that money is going to be spent.

[Robert Penta]: You have money.

[Robert Penta]: Okay.

[Robert Penta]: Thank you, Councilor Marksley.

[Robert Penta]: I appreciate it.

[Robert Penta]: I don't know if you can hear me, if it makes it any clearer.

[Robert Penta]: What Councilor Marksley has alluded to has brought me into this issue of public accounting as to what took place as it related to this

[Robert Penta]: connectivity fee, that's what it was called.

[Robert Penta]: So it was implemented in August of 2017, and for the last three years, it has brought in in excess of $3 million to the city of Medford.

[Robert Penta]: And having that at $3 million and not knowing how and what it's been used for, and if it was going to be an adjunct to the water and sewer system here in the city of Medford, then so be it.

[Robert Penta]: We always get in advance from the MWRA their projected assessment as to what the city is going to be charged for water and sewer charges.

[Robert Penta]: And that is built in your annual budget each and every year.

[Robert Penta]: And each and every year since then, the projection that this could be possibly used for a deficit has never happened because we're still dealing with the surplus.

[Robert Penta]: So I think what Councilman Marks is alluding to is the fact that, you know, if you've collected $3 million, what have you used it for, number one?

[Robert Penta]: What do you have projected for its use?

[Robert Penta]: What is the cost for it?

[Robert Penta]: And more importantly, if it is separate from water and sewer, so be it.

[Robert Penta]: As we know that you can't take the money from water and sewer because that's considered to be retained earnings.

[Robert Penta]: And the only way you can get through retained earnings is to the Department of Revenue to get a waiver and 90% of the time that they will give it to you.

[Robert Penta]: But this is something that has led me after the resolution went on, if you can just bear with me, to other things that unfortunately the council and the public have not been apprised of and brought forward.

[Robert Penta]: This base fee charge at a minimum of $51.66 annually, that's on the house side.

[Robert Penta]: I don't know what the commercial side would be.

[Robert Penta]: But if in fact it's bringing in approximately a million dollars a year, so be it.

[Robert Penta]: If you look at your most recent tax bill here in the city of Medford, which is for the third quarter, they implemented a new system with a new vendor.

[Robert Penta]: And the new vendor has really got this bill basically messed up.

[Robert Penta]: It's going to be changed because they made a big mistake on it, especially when it gets to the tax itself and it talks about your CPA tax.

[Robert Penta]: If you think about what's going on, and if you think about the taxes here that are going on here in the city of Medford, what can we do to some degree to help the Medford taxpayer as to what's going on and everything that's going on?

[Robert Penta]: So what I would like to just introduce to you is something for you to think about.

[Robert Penta]: When you look at your water and sewer tax.

[Robert Penta]: OK.

[Robert Penta]: If you can look at your water and sewer bill, and if you can look at your tax bill, I'd like to introduce something for the council entertainers.

[Robert Penta]: It's called a deadline discount program.

[Robert Penta]: And a deadline and discount program, which is implemented in a lot of states and a lot of counties, that the month that you get the bill, your tax bill, for example, you get your tax bill in November, and I believe it's due February 1st.

[Robert Penta]: The next one is February 1st.

[Robert Penta]: But if you pay it on the month that you receive it, there's a 4% discount on your bill.

[Robert Penta]: The next month, which would be January, there would be a 3% discount.

[Robert Penta]: And the city in itself would be getting its money quicker.

[Robert Penta]: And at the same time, the taxpayer would be getting a break as it relates to that.

[Robert Penta]: Same thing as it relates to your water and sewer bill.

[Robert Penta]: If you get your water and sewer bill, it's usually six or seven weeks out before you pay it.

[Robert Penta]: And the month that you get it, or the month before, you get a 4% discount if you pay for it ahead of time.

[Robert Penta]: It's a thought, but it does work because it gets the city money quicker before you get it quicker.

[Robert Penta]: Pinellas County in Florida, one of many counties, have implemented that and they've shown a marketable increase, a marketable increase.

[Robert Penta]: Another thing, Mr. President, when we talk about the city's unfunded liability, for which this council, I can go back to 2014, Resolution 214725 was offered by myself.

[Robert Penta]: And that particular resolution asked that on an annual basis, the city of Metra take out of its free cash a minimum

[Robert Penta]: of $500,000 toward then in fund liability of $29 million.

[Robert Penta]: I have no idea what the unfunded liability is.

[Robert Penta]: And I don't think this council has any idea of what the balance is and how much each and every year has been taken out of the budget for the purposes of getting to that unfunded liability, which has to be paid by 2029.

[Robert Penta]: Another thing for which the taxpayers and the council should be aware of waste management.

[Robert Penta]: And I don't know if you guys are aware of it, but in March of 2014, then Mayor McGlynn signed an extension, a three-year extension to the waste management contract in the City of Medford.

[Robert Penta]: And that three-year extension went as follows.

[Robert Penta]: For the first year, the City of Medford would get $300,000 in cash.

[Robert Penta]: The second year, they would get $100,000 more.

[Robert Penta]: That's $400,000 from 2014 going forward.

[Robert Penta]: But the catch to the whole thing was as follows.

[Robert Penta]: The amendment was, if you remember correctly, for those who did serve back then, recycling was an issue here in the city of Medford.

[Robert Penta]: And at that point in time, when the contract was signed, we were at 11%.

[Robert Penta]: At some point in time, the city worked itself up to a 29% inventory of recycling.

[Robert Penta]: But as a result of the city signing off on a three-year extension, what took place there was that the city of Medford allowed waste management, allowed waste management to increase our cost of recycling on an annual basis projected at

[Robert Penta]: $85 per ton, and then it would set itself on an annual basis increase, according to the city of Boston, beginning on July 1st, 2015.

[Robert Penta]: That's almost six months, that's almost a good year after the contract was signed.

[Robert Penta]: And as a result of that, each and every year, the city of Medford has been being charged more for recycling than they had been according to the original agreement.

[Robert Penta]: So for $300,000, $400,000 that the city got paid up front, the cost of recycling has gone forward.

[Robert Penta]: And once this contract ends in the year 2023, yeah 2023, all the recycling bins, all the recycling bins that the people have in this city will come under the control of the city of Medford.

[Robert Penta]: They'll own it and not waste management.

[Robert Penta]: Another thing that I believe, Mr. President, needs to really be discussed is the CPA.

[Robert Penta]: Once again, taxpayers on an annual basis are at a cost of approximately $103, according to your household, in the value of your home.

[Robert Penta]: Now, the CPA, as we all know, five years are up.

[Robert Penta]: Any time after five years, according to the law, as it's written, that question can go back on the ballot.

[Robert Penta]: And I would strongly suggest that this council put that question back on the ballot.

[Robert Penta]: Because when it was first elected in 2015, 1,200 people did not vote on the question because it was on the backside of the ballot, and they didn't know that the question was there to be asked.

[Robert Penta]: $103, think about that, annually for CPA.

[Robert Penta]: Then you think about the $51 and the connectivity fee, and you put that together with maybe the discounts on paying for your taxes, it would be a great help to the city of Medford and to the taxpayers.

[Robert Penta]: Also, Mr. President,

[Robert Penta]: Cable costs.

[Robert Penta]: Mr. Clerk, please call the roll.

[Robert Penta]: Mr. President, before you call the roll, one quick thing as a notation on the tax bills that come out.

[Robert Penta]: You'll notice it says police, fire, and library.

[Robert Penta]: It says 10, 25, 30, whatever it might be.

[Robert Penta]: Because that would give either an incentive or not for somebody to make a contribution.

[Robert Penta]: Thank you.

[Robert Penta]: On the bill.

[Robert Penta]: Okay, under each item it'll tell you, they can put in parentheses, that would designate how much money.

[Robert Penta]: Right.

[Robert Penta]: Summit Road.

[Robert Penta]: Mr. President, I want to go back to something that I had said earlier.

[Robert Penta]: I would like the council to entertain what they call a deadline and discount program.

[Robert Penta]: This would relate itself to your water bills and also to your taxes.

[Robert Penta]: And as I said before, it is well practiced in some states and some cities and towns where

[Robert Penta]: On the month that you receive, for example, your tax bill, if you pay it that month, you get a 4% discount.

[Robert Penta]: If you pay it the next month before the bill is due, you get a 3% discount.

[Robert Penta]: Or you wait till the very last day and pay it like a lot of people do.

[Robert Penta]: Same thing with the water bills.

[Robert Penta]: The water bills doesn't have as much of a leeway time between the tax bills when they come in.

[Robert Penta]: But in the month that you receive the bill, it's usually halfway through the month.

[Robert Penta]: If you pay it that month, it's a 4% discount.

[Robert Penta]: I think it works well because it's a handshake between the cities and the taxpayers.

[Robert Penta]: And if the taxpayer is looking for a little bit of a break, there it is right there.

[Robert Penta]: If you pay your bill ahead of time, you get a discount.

[Robert Penta]: And at the same time, the city gets its money to use at a quicker rate for whatever purpose it has.

[Robert Penta]: I think it works.

[Robert Penta]: I think it makes sense.

[Robert Penta]: And there's no loss to either side.

[Robert Penta]: I think it's a benefit to either side.

[Robert Penta]: And at the same time,

[Robert Penta]: What you're doing is you're telling the taxpayers, you're basically thinking out for them the best way you can, and you're thinking out for the city the best way you can, because you're giving us the money quicker than we would have gotten if we had to wait almost eight weeks for you to pay your tax bill.

[Robert Penta]: So I would hope someone on the council would entertain it, present it before a committee of the whole for the purposes of discussing it, and moving forward with it.

[Robert Penta]: It works.

[Robert Penta]: It works in other cities.

[Robert Penta]: It works in other states and other cities and towns.

[Robert Penta]: And as I told you earlier, it's just a way of saying to the taxpayers, we're hearing what you're saying.

[Robert Penta]: Everybody's got these problems today.

[Robert Penta]: We want to help you out.

[Robert Penta]: And the second thing on the citizen participation, I just don't understand why tax seniors have to pay that once a year $25 tax to park in the city when we were told in January inauguration that the seniors would be able to park for nothing in the city of Medford.

[Robert Penta]: That still hasn't happened yet.

[Robert Penta]: I don't know why.

[Robert Penta]: It's a promise that should have been kept, that needs to be kept, and it's just, once again, it's, I don't know.

[Robert Penta]: I don't know how the city's operating lately, but all I can tell you is this.

[Robert Penta]: You've got to look for creative ways to keep the people's interest, and at the same time, to keep your own interest.

[Robert Penta]: And what I presented here tonight, I think, is a pretty good handshake with the taxpayers and with the city of Medford as well, Mr. President.

[Robert Penta]: Be more than happy.

[Robert Penta]: When we talk about money here in the city of Medford, you talk about how the city is going to function.

[Robert Penta]: And the city can only function when the taxpayers are willing to pay.

[Robert Penta]: And sometimes people become delinquent in paying.

[Robert Penta]: And if they become delinquent, they can't pay it because they don't have it.

[Robert Penta]: And if those people that do have it want to relinquish some of their money quicker,

[Robert Penta]: and get a discount for doing it, it helps the city because they get the money quicker.

[Robert Penta]: And the last thing I want to say, Mr. President, I think it really needs to entertain itself that the CPA, which is now five years has come and gone, should be looked at about presenting itself on the ballot this November coming in 2021 for the purposes of whether you're going to use it again and re-up it and what have you, because that's what the law says.

[Robert Penta]: I'm not advocating for it or against it.

[Robert Penta]: What I'm advocating is that the five years are up.

[Robert Penta]: The sunset legislation is now in effect.

[Robert Penta]: And if you don't do nothing, it's just going to stay there.

[Robert Penta]: 1,200 people in 2015 did not vote on that question because it was on the opposite side of the ballot.

[Robert Penta]: They weren't aware it was there.

[Robert Penta]: So we really have no idea.

[Robert Penta]: whether it would have passed or it didn't pass.

[Robert Penta]: This time, I think it would be incumbent if the question goes on the ballot, it's there, and the taxpayers make their decision.

[Robert Penta]: That's what it's about, the taxpayers' use of their money.

[Robert Penta]: I'd be more than happy to answer any questions.

[Robert Penta]: Thank you, Councilor Penta.

[Robert Penta]: Thank you.

[Robert Penta]: Mr. President.

[Robert Penta]: Thank you.

[Robert Penta]: Mr. President.

[Robert Penta]: It's how a city sets its tax rate and how it makes its collections.

[Robert Penta]: Good evening, my name is Robert Penta, Zero Summit Road, and a former member of the August body.

[Robert Penta]: If that's true, I don't know.

[Robert Penta]: Is it true?

[Robert Penta]: So he says we hope so.

[Robert Penta]: First of all, going back to last year at some point in time regarding the Lawrence Memorial Hospital, we never got a report back from the auditor's office as it relates to the outpatient surgical offices that are going to be housed

[Robert Penta]: in the old Lawrence Memorial Hospital as part of an addendum to the 16,000 square foot building that the Lawrence Memorial Hospital is going to have their surgical center at.

[Robert Penta]: And where they're going to be running a funeral business out of that center, once again, it presents itself as a for-profit business within the non-profit structure itself.

[Robert Penta]: Again, no answers come back on that as of yet.

[Robert Penta]: At that point in time, Councilor Caraviello indicated during his first term, it was $1.2 million of school repairs.

[Robert Penta]: We're now in excess of $1.5 million of school repairs, and we're getting ourselves right into the same position, I shouldn't say ourselves, the city is getting itself into this position

[Robert Penta]: of why we had to build new schools in the first place.

[Robert Penta]: If the upkeep is not going to be taking place, there is something wrong with that.

[Robert Penta]: The building of a new police station, contained within the building of the new police station, it's 5,000 square feet less than what was asked for.

[Robert Penta]: There is no police firing range that is for qualification.

[Robert Penta]: But more importantly, the sad part about the whole thing, no police vehicle is going to be able to be housed internally.

[Robert Penta]: They're all going to be outside.

[Robert Penta]: And by doing that, all you're doing is leaving all your public service vehicles open to the elements.

[Robert Penta]: So if there's a snowstorm or whatever it might be, every police officer's gonna have to go out there and take the snow off it.

[Robert Penta]: And you try to explain that to the people of this community and you tell them that you're spending close to $20 million for a new police station, but you have no place to house or at least care for your police cruisers.

[Robert Penta]: A very important issue that seems to be lost in the weeds is the, at present, if not more, a $29 million unfunded pension liability that needs to be paid by 2029.

[Robert Penta]: That is yet to be discussed.

[Robert Penta]: Also, what needs to be addressed right now also is a citywide

[Robert Penta]: It's called the Citywide Home Water Meter Battery Replacement Program.

[Robert Penta]: Now for those of you that have a house and you know when you get your water and sewer bill, the system was put in well over 10 years ago with meters that were only good for 10 years.

[Robert Penta]: The 10 years have come and gone, that's a cost factor and that's a replacement that needs to take place.

[Robert Penta]: We still have yet to receive a cost projection for a new fire station as to where it will be, when it will be, and what it will cost.

[Robert Penta]: There is no projections out there.

[Robert Penta]: And still outstanding is the new training tower that was promised it would be built before the old one was taken down.

[Robert Penta]: Well, the old one has been taken down, and now nothing has been put up.

[Robert Penta]: And in fact, it does affect, in the city of Medford, your home insurance rates.

[Robert Penta]: There's no financial outline as to how the city's annual free cash should be prioritized.

[Robert Penta]: For the new councils coming on board, for the last few many years, it's almost a million dollars each and every year the city of Medford has left over, it just goes into free cash.

[Robert Penta]: So that presents itself with one or two arguments.

[Robert Penta]: Number one, the budget is either not accurate, or number two, that million dollars is maybe not correct when the budget is being voted upon at the time.

[Robert Penta]: So therefore,

[Robert Penta]: To me, it makes very good sense because a lot of cities and towns do this.

[Robert Penta]: You folks pass a budget in May or June, let's call it June, that should be the time you set your tax rate, not six months later.

[Robert Penta]: So if you do that, you're working on an actual annual budget that reflects upon that vote that took place in June that represents itself to each and every dollar itemized.

[Robert Penta]: That would be a great program to have because number one, we're already understaffed and we're hiring immediately just two more people to work in the highway department that just basically on a daily basis is so understaffed and on demand.

[Robert Penta]: Once again, a rumored development of 30 plus condos on South Street.

[Robert Penta]: Now, some six months later,

[Robert Penta]: This same company, Combined Properties, is now proposing a 37, 378 residential unit, and the application for approval is coming along under a Chapter 40B proposal, entirely different than what they originally had.

[Robert Penta]: Neighborhood protests pushed it back.

[Robert Penta]: And the reason why the moratorium would work

[Robert Penta]: is because our zoning has not been reviewed for a multitude of years.

[Robert Penta]: So sure, they'll give you their affordable housing.

[Robert Penta]: but they'll back in the cost on the remaining units that are in the building.

[Robert Penta]: I don't know.

[Robert Penta]: My name is Robert Pentez, Zero Summit Road, Medford, Mass.

[Robert Penta]: The stress and anxiety of Clipgate, that's what I call it, Clipgate, has needlessly caused our city an embarrassed showing for collective management when they thought nobody was looking.

[Robert Penta]: Dating back to December 28th, when the ammo clip was first found,

[Robert Penta]: A cast of characters have become principal components to the investigation, starting with the cleaning company personnel who first found the clip.

[Robert Penta]: We have further parties of interest in the school custodian, Mr. Edwards, the principal at the McGlynn School, Mr. Belson, the school superintendent, the resource officer, Medford police officer, Riccati, Mr. McLaughlin, director of building and grounds, Mayor Burke, and school employees who brought this to the attention of Councilor Lungo-Koehn.

[Robert Penta]: When Councilor Lungo-Koehn notified the police on Thursday, December 15th, of this concern brought to her attention by school employees, the school building was swept on Tuesday, February 20th, according to news reports.

[Robert Penta]: Thankfully, Breanna Lungo-Koehn and Councilor Marks addressed this matter at their next council meeting with many concerned parents in attendance.

[Robert Penta]: This past Thursday, February 22nd,

[Robert Penta]: at the Karen Little Theater at Medford High School.

[Robert Penta]: Seven days after Breonna Lungelkorn notified police, the mayor called for a school committee meeting wherein hundreds of Medford citizens, teachers, and administrators attended to discuss the matter.

[Robert Penta]: When Mayor Burke, as chairperson of the school committee, first found out about this matter, and from whom and what did she do, she has yet to disclose that matter.

[Robert Penta]: While the February 22nd meeting revealed a lot of anger and displeasure as to what the Clipgate incident has caused, it also revealed shortcomings to questions asked.

[Robert Penta]: One glaring question, and yet to be answered, was, who was the we that decided not to share the info at the outset?

[Robert Penta]: The Medford Police, under the direction of Chief Sacco, is leading the in-house investigation regarding this incident, as he should.

[Robert Penta]: If the Medford police are good enough to investigate a murder, stolen property, drug dealing, and other crimes within their daily jobs, they now don't need to be upstaged by the mayor and her hiring of her close, personal, and financially rewarding political friend, Martha Coakley.

[Robert Penta]: Mayor Burke, on her own, without any discussion, approval, or vote of record from the school committee, has hired her close personal friend, former Attorney General Martha Coakley, who has contributed $1,000 to Mayor Burke's campaign to do this independent personnel investigation because of this matter as it's reported in the news reports.

[Robert Penta]: This independent personnel investigation should have no ties nor relationships to any politicians in our cities.

[Robert Penta]: I ask, where is the transparency to this matter?

[Robert Penta]: Independent means just what it says.

[Robert Penta]: Free and devoid from any influence, guidance, or counsel of another or others, nor affiliated with or loyal to no one political party, organization, or voter.

[Robert Penta]: Both Mrs. Burke and Mrs. Coakley are both Democrats.

[Robert Penta]: This hiring of Martha Coakley by Mayor Burke is a sole source contract, a contract awarded without competitive bidding.

[Robert Penta]: It directs itself to cronyism, particularly in awarding jobs to friends or trusted colleagues in politics between politicians.

[Robert Penta]: This hiring also prevents presents, excuse me, a serious question as to whether Mayor Burke has violated the state ethics law on the chapter 62.

[Robert Penta]: Massachusetts General Law, Chapter 268A, wherein the law states if a conflict is apparent, or the appearance is a telling sign, then a violation of the law is readily at hand.

[Robert Penta]: A public employee may not act in a manner that would cause a reasonable person to think that she would show favor toward someone or that she can be improperly influenced.

[Robert Penta]: I stand here not to question the ability or the capability

[Robert Penta]: of Martha Coakley, but rather the concern of a state ethics conflict of interest, as well as to her individual unspecified cost from her very expensive downtown Boston law firm of Foley and Hogue.

[Robert Penta]: Mayor Burke's relationship with Martha Coakley has been long and financially rewarding.

[Robert Penta]: I find it interesting that Mayor Burke is now concerned with having an independent personnel investigation, but where is her outside independent audit of the school department if she is so concerned about righting the ship?

[Robert Penta]: I do not believe we need a very expensive, close, personal, and political friend of the mayor to address Medford's employee personnel policies.

[Robert Penta]: Medford is a good city with tons of good people in it.

[Robert Penta]: Let this incident be the thoughtful reminder that when the law is not followed and protocols are not in place, and when city leaders take it upon themselves to make decisions that fly in the face of potential safety and what the law says,

[Robert Penta]: then all involved, no matter who, as this case has demonstrated, shall be held accountable.

[Robert Penta]: For the truth only has one consequence.

[Robert Penta]: Let no cover-up be worse than the crime itself.

[Robert Penta]: I would like to conclude by making a correction to a statement I made last Thursday at the school committee meeting.

[Robert Penta]: At the conclusion of my commentary and in my haste, I misread what I meant to say, and it was as follows, what I meant to say.

[Robert Penta]: What happened in Florida was horrific, and hopefully we all have learned something here tonight.

[Robert Penta]: The people of Medford want action, and as city officials, you owe it to them.

[Robert Penta]: Now, with that being said, Mr. President, again,

[Robert Penta]: You folks have been through the whole issue of conflict of interest, whether it be your pay raises or jobs.

[Robert Penta]: This is a very serious matter.

[Robert Penta]: This hiring of Mrs. Coakley out of the Clear Blue Sky, while this incident is going on, I believe does not speak well for the police investigation.

[Robert Penta]: I don't think it speaks well for the Medford Police Department.

[Robert Penta]: They can handle their own investigation, and if it turns out to be

[Robert Penta]: something on one of their own, they will resolve it.

[Robert Penta]: If it's something that's resolved here in the building, an employee, it will be resolved internally.

[Robert Penta]: Robert Penta, Zero Summit Road, Medford, Mass., former member of this August body.

[Robert Penta]: I come here to address the City Council on this important issue that has important but different consequences depending on what side of the issue that you might be on.

[Robert Penta]: At the outset, I want to address and thank Curtis Tudin for propelling this issue

[Robert Penta]: before our citizens of the city of Medford.

[Robert Penta]: Since this is an election year and we're all running for office, those of you that are and those that might be candidates running for office, boasting about all the wonderful accomplishments and the hard votes that you had to take.

[Robert Penta]: To me, this is a very important issue and I think it's an issue that needs to be presented and discussed and to have everybody, including the mayor, the city council, the school committee, take a position on this issue.

[Robert Penta]: Because isn't it weird, when we think about our America today, and you see all the things that are taking place, whether it's before the National Football League, or little Pop Warner kids, the use of our American flag, the national anthem, seems to be at issue.

[Robert Penta]: And our culture seems to be at issue.

[Robert Penta]: But where are we going with all of that?

[Robert Penta]: I don't know.

[Robert Penta]: Sanctuary City's had its beginning here in the United States back in the 1980s.

[Robert Penta]: Central folks, central people from Central America left their country looking for political refuge because of the oppressive nature that was taking place.

[Robert Penta]: And what took place here in this country, and the churches, many of the churches throughout this country, they took these folks in, believing them to be in need of help, and for which we did, we helped them out.

[Robert Penta]: But that sort of like has morphed itself since 1981 to what it is today, addressing itself to sanctuary cities.

[Robert Penta]: And as a result of sanctuary cities becoming what they are and having a different interpretation, you, Mr. President, just read something that was dated November 21, 2016.

[Robert Penta]: If you go to that third whereas, it says the city of Medford stands in support of all immigrant groups.

[Robert Penta]: I think the word before all,

[Robert Penta]: an immigrant should be legal.

[Robert Penta]: All legal immigrant groups.

[Robert Penta]: Because we, the people of the United States, are a nation built on laws.

[Robert Penta]: Its foundation is built on laws.

[Robert Penta]: And it's on the legality of what we do each and every day.

[Robert Penta]: And it seems, and it seems that because of all this illegal immigration that is taking place in this country, you know, have we as a country now forgotten the fact or gotten to the point where everybody has a right

[Robert Penta]: We're giving everybody rights, but nobody wants responsibility.

[Robert Penta]: But the responsibility that's being borne each and every day is the Mr. and Mrs. America, Mr. and Mrs. Medford taxpayer.

[Robert Penta]: You know, I cannot think of any prouder comment than something that's written on the banner of the VFW of Mystic Avenue.

[Robert Penta]: It says, all lives matter.

[Robert Penta]: Everybody's lives matter.

[Robert Penta]: White, black, blue, green, I don't care what nationality you are.

[Robert Penta]: If you're here in this country, and you're here legally, or you have the proper legal documents, earning your way to become an American citizen, your life matters.

[Robert Penta]: And for those folks that come here illegally, that's in and of itself the question that's before us right now.

[Robert Penta]: We as a community are very generous to so many people.

[Robert Penta]: You members on the council, especially your two new members, Councilor Scarpel and Councilor Falco, you've just gone through two years of community block grant funding, and if you go through each and every one of those community block grant fundings, you will see the amount of money that's been dedicated and prioritized to charities within not only the city of Medford, but in the Tri-City and outside the city of Medford.

[Robert Penta]: You've also seen monies go to legal, council,

[Robert Penta]: for people who have an illegal immigration condition needing to get itself resolved and coming forward.

[Robert Penta]: We also have in this community all our churches and all the food pantries and the shelters taking care of as many people as they can.

[Robert Penta]: And while they're doing that, the question then becomes, who comes first, the illegal or the legal?

[Robert Penta]: And I think a sanctuary city, in and of itself,

[Robert Penta]: presents that particular situation.

[Robert Penta]: Like I said, again, depending on what side of the issue you're on.

[Robert Penta]: Sanctuary cities throughout this country, and there's 200 of them right now, that bar the use of government resources to enforce federal immigration laws.

[Robert Penta]: And they also allow illegals charged with crimes to be released without notifying federal authorities.

[Robert Penta]: Now, in a report that was submitted in December of 2014 to Congress,

[Robert Penta]: It stated that more than 30,000 convicted criminals have been released by ICE at the end of 2014, and they have gone back to the states, to the cities and towns that they came from.

[Robert Penta]: But inclusive of those crimes,

[Robert Penta]: There was 173 homicides, there were 373 sexual assaults, there were 186 kidnappings, and there was 1,000, excuse me, there was 14,014 drunk driving charges to individuals that did not have a license.

[Robert Penta]: There were more than 30,000 convicted criminal citations issued during that time.

[Robert Penta]: What does that say to the law abiding citizen?

[Robert Penta]: But more importantly, what does that say to law enforcement personnel?

[Robert Penta]: Who especially now, if you're in a sanctuary city, you can't ask for identification as to are you an immigrant or not.

[Robert Penta]: You can't hold them, you can't call ISIS, excuse me.

[Robert Penta]: It has a ramification that just really says to the police officer of today, beside doing my job for the city that I'm in, I am now having to become aware of somebody who might be here illegally.

[Robert Penta]: And that person might get preferential treatment over someone who might be here legally, but that I can arrest and imprison.

[Robert Penta]: And that's really not right.

[Robert Penta]: There's a particular case that takes place from a gentleman and his two children that died.

[Robert Penta]: He came from Levone, Texas.

[Robert Penta]: And he was hit by an illegal immigrant who hit him head on in a collision.

[Robert Penta]: And he killed him, his four-year-old son, and his 22-month-old, strike that, his four-year-old daughter and his 22-month-old son.

[Robert Penta]: The illegal person was arrested and plea bargained to a two-year sentence.

[Robert Penta]: a two-year sentence for wiping out a husband, a father, and a daughter.

[Robert Penta]: The woman, subsequent to that, has had some kind of public, how could you say, retaliation, because she felt that the justice system didn't do her right, because she complained because of that, and the person that killed her husband, her daughter, and her son was Hispanic, she now becomes the culprit and not the victim.

[Robert Penta]: These are just little nuances.

[Robert Penta]: We can go to the entire country.

[Robert Penta]: There are cases where police officers have been killed, shot, brutally murdered by illegal immigrants here in this country.

[Robert Penta]: And that's not right.

[Robert Penta]: Absolutely not right.

[Robert Penta]: When we think about what's going on, illegals, they have the benefits of our free medical system.

[Robert Penta]: They go to our quality schools.

[Robert Penta]: They get free housing and free food.

[Robert Penta]: But they don't choose to blend in

[Robert Penta]: by learning English and assimilating to our American culture.

[Robert Penta]: And further, by committing crimes outside or inside the community or the state that they're in, it adds a definite cost to our police, to our public safety, to our public education, and to Mr. and Mrs. Medford and Mr. and Mrs. America.

[Robert Penta]: So the question then becomes, on a sanctuary city, you folks are running for office.

[Robert Penta]: I haven't seen one of you yet say or put anywhere in your literature.

[Robert Penta]: Just one gentleman so far, he's in the back of the room, made the point that he is for sanctuary cities.

[Robert Penta]: I commend him for it.

[Robert Penta]: He took his position.

[Robert Penta]: It's a very important issue to be discussed.

[Robert Penta]: Because if you're telling me that you're abiding by this November 16th, strike that, November 23rd,

[Robert Penta]: resolution, well, this smacks of all the ingredients of a sanctuary city.

[Robert Penta]: Either we are or we're not.

[Robert Penta]: And I think you councilors and every candidate running for office needs to take that position.

[Robert Penta]: And the reason why they need to take that position, whether you're for or against, in a common level headed society, while we don't have to agree, we can respectfully disagree.

[Robert Penta]: And that's where I think we need to be going here in this community.

[Robert Penta]: You know, when you say we're a welcoming community, as a matter of fact, there's a billboard coming in on Route 93.

[Robert Penta]: It says we are a welcoming.

[Robert Penta]: We've always been a welcoming committee.

[Robert Penta]: We've got the third largest black population in the Commonwealth of Massachusetts, and we've had it for years.

[Robert Penta]: And slowly but surely, they're leaving because nobody can afford to stay there anymore.

[Robert Penta]: The cost of housing in this community has gone completely out of control.

[Robert Penta]: Makes no sense at all.

[Robert Penta]: And if this present administration keeps wanting to put housing all over the place, and if this council doesn't want to review zoning, that's what's going to happen.

[Robert Penta]: You can have a city so out of control, you're not going to be able to understand what's going on.

[Robert Penta]: And Dr. Stirella was right.

[Robert Penta]: Your finances will be so out of control.

[Robert Penta]: And if you add a sanctuary city to the mix, then please explain why you're doing it.

[Robert Penta]: And please let the people know as a candidate for office that a sanctuary city, you're either for it or against it.

[Robert Penta]: Mr. Panto, we're running, you're running over your time.

[Robert Penta]: I think the bottom line, my comment would basically, I don't think any city council, any mayor, any school committee person or anyone

[Robert Penta]: should tell a police department how to do their job, especially whether they're legal or illegal.

[Robert Penta]: That's their job to protect and to serve, and not to be controlled by a political hierarchy in a community that turns around and says, we want to be a sanctuary city.

[Robert Penta]: Thank you.

[Robert Penta]: Robert Penteciro, Summit Road, Medford, Mass.

[Robert Penta]: First of all, for the young lady to my behind me,

[Robert Penta]: I'm not a white privileged individual.

[Robert Penta]: I've had to work for everything in my life, starting at five o'clock in the morning for eight consecutive years, driving a canteen truck, being held up three times, shot at twice.

[Robert Penta]: But I didn't give up because I knew what I wanted to do.

[Robert Penta]: I wanted to get a college education and go forward with my life.

[Robert Penta]: And that's what I did.

[Robert Penta]: I did not come here tonight to be decisive or

[Robert Penta]: Have people become decisive.

[Robert Penta]: I came here tonight to present an issue, thanking Mr. Tudin, who made the acknowledgement that he is for a sanctuary city.

[Robert Penta]: It's a subject matter that needs to be discussed.

[Robert Penta]: The statistics that were given are actual statistics.

[Robert Penta]: You can't get away because they're not lying.

[Robert Penta]: And for the other lady who indicated that the crime rate for the individuals who are undocumented are less than regular American citizens that are documented and are legal, that in and of itself spells to the question of the police department.

[Robert Penta]: They're doing more work because they have to deal with undocumented illegals over and beyond their regular course.

[Robert Penta]: Now, are all of them bad people?

[Robert Penta]: Absolutely not.

[Robert Penta]: Do they deserve a fair shot?

[Robert Penta]: Absolutely.

[Robert Penta]: And if they have to have some political intervention, which is taking place right now in Washington, so be it.

[Robert Penta]: But the fact of the matter is this.

[Robert Penta]: I stand here and I resent the fact that anyone, any seven of you or anyone in this audience, who wants to turn around and say, because I was born white, that I am privileged, that is false, that is wrong, and that is a lie.

[Robert Penta]: And you should be ashamed of yourself for saying that.

[Robert Penta]: Thank you.

[Robert Penta]: Robert Penta, Zero Summit Road, Medford Mass, former member of this August body.

[Robert Penta]: I come here to address the City Council on this important issue that has important but different consequences depending on what side of the issue that you might be on.

[Robert Penta]: At the outset, I want to address and thank Curtis Tooden for propelling this issue.

[Robert Penta]: before our citizens of the city of Medford.

[Robert Penta]: Since this is an election year and we're all running for office, those of you that are and those that might be candidates running for office, boasting about all the wonderful accomplishments and the hard votes that you had to take.

[Robert Penta]: To me, this is a very important issue and I think it's an issue that needs to be presented and discussed and to have everybody, including the mayor, the city council and the school committee take a position on this issue.

[Robert Penta]: Because isn't it weird, when we think about our America today and you see all the things that are taking place, whether it's before the National Football League or Little Pop Wanna Kids, the use of our American flag, the national anthem, seems to be at issue.

[Robert Penta]: And our culture seems to be at issue.

[Robert Penta]: But where are we going with all of that?

[Robert Penta]: I don't know.

[Robert Penta]: You know, Sanctuary City's had its beginning here in the United States back in the 1980s.

[Robert Penta]: Central folks, central people from Central America left their country looking for political refuge because of the oppressive nature that was taking place.

[Robert Penta]: And what took place here in this country, and the churches, many of the churches throughout this country, they took these folks in, believing them to be in need of help, and for which we did, we helped them out.

[Robert Penta]: But that sort of like has morphed itself since 1981 to what it is today, addressing itself to sanctuary cities.

[Robert Penta]: And as a result of sanctuary cities becoming what they are and having a different interpretation, you, Mr. President, just read something that was dated November 21, 2016.

[Robert Penta]: If you go to that third whereas, it says the city of Medford stands in support of all immigrant groups.

[Robert Penta]: I think the word before all

[Robert Penta]: an immigrant should be legal.

[Robert Penta]: All legal immigrant groups.

[Robert Penta]: Because we, the people of the United States, are a nation built on laws.

[Robert Penta]: Its foundation is built on laws.

[Robert Penta]: And it's on the legality of what we do each and every day.

[Robert Penta]: And it seems, and it seems that because of all this illegal immigration that is taking place in this country, you know, have we as a country now forgotten the fact or gotten to the point where everybody has a right

[Robert Penta]: We're giving everybody rights, but nobody wants responsibility.

[Robert Penta]: But the responsibility that's being borne each and every day is the Mr. and Mrs. America, Mr. and Mrs. Medford Taxpayer.

[Robert Penta]: You know, I cannot think of any prouder comment than something that's written on the banner of the VFW of Mystic Avenue.

[Robert Penta]: It says, all lives matter.

[Robert Penta]: Everybody's lives matter.

[Robert Penta]: White, black, blue, green.

[Robert Penta]: I don't care what nationality you are.

[Robert Penta]: If you're here in this country and you're here legally or you have the proper legal documents earning your way to become an American citizen, your life matters.

[Robert Penta]: And for those folks that come here illegally, that's in and of itself the question that's before us right now.

[Robert Penta]: You know,

[Robert Penta]: We as a community are very generous to so many people.

[Robert Penta]: You members on the council, especially your two new members, Councilor Scarpel and Councilor Falco, you've just gone through two years of community block grant funding.

[Robert Penta]: And if you go through each and every one of those community block grant fundings, you will see the amount of money that's been dedicated and prioritized to charities within not only the city of Medford, but in the Tri-City and outside the city of Medford.

[Robert Penta]: You've also seen monies go to legal, council,

[Robert Penta]: for people who have an illegal immigration condition needing to get itself resolved and coming forward.

[Robert Penta]: We also have in this community all our churches and all the food pantries and the shelters taking care of as many people as they can.

[Robert Penta]: And while they're doing that, the question then becomes, who comes first, the illegal or the legal?

[Robert Penta]: And I think a sanctuary city, in and of itself,

[Robert Penta]: presents that particular situation.

[Robert Penta]: Like I said, again, depending on what side of the issue you're on.

[Robert Penta]: Sanctuary cities throughout this country, and there's 200 of them right now, that bar the use of government resources to enforce federal immigration laws.

[Robert Penta]: And they also allow illegals charged with crimes to be released without notifying federal authorities.

[Robert Penta]: Now, in a report that was submitted in December of 2014 to Congress,

[Robert Penta]: It stated that more than 30,000 convicted criminals have been released by ICE at the end of 2014, and they have gone back to the states, to the cities and towns that they came from.

[Robert Penta]: But inclusive of those crimes, there was 173 homicides, there were 373 sexual assaults, there were 186 kidnappings, and there was 1,000, excuse me, there was 14,014

[Robert Penta]: drunk driving charges to individuals that did not have a license.

[Robert Penta]: There were more than 30,000 convicted criminal citations issued during that time.

[Robert Penta]: What does that say to the law abiding citizen?

[Robert Penta]: But more importantly, what does that say to law enforcement personnel?

[Robert Penta]: who especially now, if you're in a sanctuary city, you can't ask for identification as to are you an immigrant or not, you can't hold them, you can't call ISIS, excuse me.
