[Robert Penta]: And that's all that it is.

[Robert Penta]: And you move on from the subject matter.

[Robert Penta]: And what's really interesting here, there's three people here that were, you people were that young when they first started?

[Robert Penta]: I don't believe it.

[Robert Penta]: But I'm not that old, so that's the point, okay?

[Robert Penta]: So I want to wish you good luck.

[Robert Penta]: Like him, I don't think he's going away.

[Robert Penta]: He'll be around, and he's just taking a pause in life, and that's okay.

[Robert Penta]: And sometimes you need to do that to refine yourself and get yourself back in action.

[Robert Penta]: So I congratulate you.

[Robert Penta]: Enjoy your life.

[Robert Penta]: Enjoy your wife and your family, because that's what it's really about.

[Robert Penta]: The first thing in life is your family, and that's what you take care of.

[Robert Penta]: Good luck.

[Robert Penta]: You know, I had a big speech prepared, but the first thing I'm going to say, I'm not retiring, and I'm not going to Florida.

[Robert Penta]: I'm staying right here in the city of Medford, all right?

[Robert Penta]: First of all, and more importantly, you know, I was getting a little emotional sitting over there, and I was at a point maybe getting a little teary-eyed.

[Robert Penta]: But you know something?

[Robert Penta]: I'm not going to do that tonight.

[Robert Penta]: Tonight, this is a congratulatory night for me.

[Robert Penta]: I am so thankful that I have had an opportunity for serving in government for 36 years that was never once questioned as it relates to who or what I was about and why I was doing what I did.

[Robert Penta]: I did it for one particular reason.

[Robert Penta]: I was elected by the people of this community to represent them to the best of my ability.

[Robert Penta]: not for any personal, financial, or family gain.

[Robert Penta]: I did this for one reason, because you, the people, are the most important people in this community.

[Robert Penta]: That's why you elect folks like us, to be here and to do your business and to represent your finances, your education, and your wherewithal to the best of my ability.

[Robert Penta]: When I first ran for office in 1974, I ran for state representative and I got elected.

[Robert Penta]: There was a lady that I met.

[Robert Penta]: And she happened to turn out to be the first woman mayor of the city of Medford.

[Robert Penta]: Her name was Marilyn Catino Perica.

[Robert Penta]: And she gave me... She gave me a guidepost that I used in this very past election.

[Robert Penta]: It basically was, true leadership is found in the plan that one has to offer for respectful consideration.

[Robert Penta]: As we all know, I did not run for re-election to the Medford City Council this past year.

[Robert Penta]: I ran for the office of mayor.

[Robert Penta]: At the outset, I want to thank Anthony D'Antonio, because four years ago, he broke the ice, saying in this community, someone can run against the mayor.

[Robert Penta]: No one is invincible, no one owns the job.

[Robert Penta]: Unfortunately, he didn't make it, but he tried, and he got 36% of the vote.

[Robert Penta]: That's a huge number to get, coming out of the box for the very first time.

[Robert Penta]: I decided to run for this job this past time, only for one reason.

[Robert Penta]: to present a plan, a plan that would give you a vision, a plan that would give you an opportunity, and a plan that would tell you how your taxes and how your buildings and how your educational system would work.

[Robert Penta]: I have to thank my wife, Susan.

[Robert Penta]: She was the campaign manager to my campaign, and you know, I don't know why, she never was involved in politics before.

[Robert Penta]: I needed and wanted someone who could talk to me and relate to the, as the person on the street,

[Robert Penta]: and you can't say this, and this is what you should be doing, and how do we make this connection work?

[Robert Penta]: She stabilized me during this campaign, because everyone knows, at the drop of a dime, I could lose it, and I have, and I have, and I'll admit it, and I have, and I have probably at council meetings in the past through the years, and that's only because of my passion for the job.

[Robert Penta]: That's not because of any hate for or against any one person or any one issue.

[Robert Penta]: You know, the one thing this community really has to figure out, and with all due respect to the incoming administration, this election was not a landslide victory.

[Robert Penta]: So there's a lot of work to be done here to make this city go in the right direction and to bring people together.

[Robert Penta]: And to bring people together, there has to be an understanding that folks need to be involved.

[Robert Penta]: And how do you get involved?

[Robert Penta]: You need to speak up.

[Robert Penta]: You come to that podium on a Tuesday night or whatever it might be.

[Robert Penta]: I will assure you of this.

[Robert Penta]: I may be sitting there now up until January 4th, but I'll be behind that rail after January 4th, because if I think there's something... Because if I believe that there is something of major importance to our community, no voice should be stifled, past, present, or the future.

[Robert Penta]: Because that's what it's all about.

[Robert Penta]: I'm 71 years old, and I'm proud of it.

[Robert Penta]: But I'm not old.

[Robert Penta]: I'm not going to sit in a rocking chair, and I'm not going away.

[Robert Penta]: Two particular points I want to bring up.

[Robert Penta]: And I think it definitely needs to be cleared up.

[Robert Penta]: because it was misdirected during this past campaign for mayor.

[Robert Penta]: I was never against new schools.

[Robert Penta]: What I was against was the opportunity for the people of Medford to have voted for new schools.

[Robert Penta]: That's number one.

[Robert Penta]: Number two, you were taking away your community schools.

[Robert Penta]: So when we went to 14 schools down to four, that was a huge change in this community.

[Robert Penta]: And a lot of people did not have their input into that.

[Robert Penta]: And as a result of that, and the reason why we built new schools at that point in time, some 15 years ago, was the schools were becoming run down.

[Robert Penta]: They were becoming misused or not used correctly, and they needed a lot of repairs.

[Robert Penta]: Well, here we are now, some 15 years later.

[Robert Penta]: Rick Caviale, on his first year on the term, that's four years ago, that would have made it 11 years ago, produced a paper that said the new schools are $1,102,000 in repairs.

[Robert Penta]: We're right back to where we were.

[Robert Penta]: That's why we built the new schools.

[Robert Penta]: There is the need to making sure that the new council, the new school committee stays on top of their buildings, because look right up there.

[Robert Penta]: That's almost three years old.

[Robert Penta]: Three years old, and the city has yet to fix that.

[Robert Penta]: And the superintendent of schools was sitting right over there when that ceiling fell, and it still hasn't been fixed.

[Robert Penta]: People, you've got to be involved.

[Robert Penta]: You need to stay involved.

[Robert Penta]: You know, I'm over this feeling right now of being sad.

[Robert Penta]: I'm not sad.

[Robert Penta]: I'm glad because I have created a new family for myself, a family of people not only who believe, but they need and they want the change to take place in this community.

[Robert Penta]: They don't want it.

[Robert Penta]: You know, this past election presented an awful lot of opportunities for everyone.

[Robert Penta]: Opportunities for people to write for or write against.

[Robert Penta]: Whether you liked me or didn't like me, whether you liked my opponent, whether you liked my Councilors or not.

[Robert Penta]: You have two brand new Councilors, you have two brand new school committee people.

[Robert Penta]: That in and of itself should open up big doors for the people in this community who want to see how and where their election process is going.

[Robert Penta]: And do they vote for the right people?

[Robert Penta]: The only way you're gonna find out if you vote for the right people, don't wait for two years and wait for the campaign literature to come out.

[Robert Penta]: Watch, as I will, each and every week and each and every month, what's taking place on the school committee, what's taking place at the city council.

[Robert Penta]: And if you don't like it, speak up, I'll call your council, I'll call your school committee person.

[Robert Penta]: You just can't be a lump in the log and say, I'm against it, I don't like it, you need to speak up.

[Robert Penta]: And people did speak up in this last election.

[Robert Penta]: Unfortunately, it was a beautiful day, only 38% of the people came out to vote.

[Robert Penta]: Hopefully, I think on both sides, everybody would have thought more people would have come out.

[Robert Penta]: But they didn't.

[Robert Penta]: But the 38 percent, they spoke.

[Robert Penta]: It was close, and I think we'll all acknowledge the fact it was close.

[Robert Penta]: So there's no mandate one way or the other.

[Robert Penta]: But there is one mandate, and that's this.

[Robert Penta]: I think the people of this community expect the elected politicians to do their job on behalf of the people of this community.

[Robert Penta]: And that's what I did for 36 years.

[Robert Penta]: I did my job, and I'm proud of the fact that I did do it.

[Robert Penta]: You know, there's always people during the campaign that you want to acknowledge.

[Robert Penta]: And there's so many.

[Robert Penta]: I could look at this entire audience.

[Robert Penta]: But to me, he's my unsung hero in each and every one of my campaigns.

[Robert Penta]: Whenever I ask him to do anything, he just does it.

[Robert Penta]: And there's no questions asked.

[Robert Penta]: And that's my brother, Anthony.

[Robert Penta]: And I have to publicly acknowledge him, because that's what he is.

[Robert Penta]: And I just caught her eye in the back of the room.

[Robert Penta]: And I want to publicly acknowledge you, Nancy.

[Robert Penta]: You came here on behalf of the Perica family.

[Robert Penta]: She and her family stood out at the polls for me on Election Day because they believed in me, and I thank you very much.

[Robert Penta]: Nancy Perica.

[Robert Penta]: You know, we could go on and on with stories here.

[Robert Penta]: And the second thing, I told you about the schools.

[Robert Penta]: And the second thing are the kiosks here in the square.

[Robert Penta]: As you all know, I'm just dead set against them.

[Robert Penta]: I don't think they're working right.

[Robert Penta]: I don't think they, I don't think that, you know, you know, there's, there's a resolution on the council agenda here tonight and it reflects upon the fact that during this past campaign, my opponent put out a questionnaire as it relates to senior citizens.

[Robert Penta]: Should they be allowed to park for nothing?

[Robert Penta]: Not only do I support that, if we're going to tweak it, then let it be tweaked and give some benefit back to this community.

[Robert Penta]: And I would hope that this city council holds the president administration

[Robert Penta]: feet to the fire by telling the Republic parking people that seniors do not have to park here.

[Robert Penta]: It's bad enough that you get taxed for everything else, and 45 percent of this community is made up of seniors.

[Robert Penta]: Give them a break, folks, because you get the water, you get the meals tax, you get the hotel tax, and you get your real estate tax, and anything else you want to talk about just keeps going up in this community.

[Robert Penta]: And while everything keeps going up in this community, salaries have not gotten up.

[Robert Penta]: Everyone that works in this building works for you.

[Robert Penta]: Your taxpaying dollars pay for everyone's job in this particular building.

[Robert Penta]: To get your biggest bank for the buck, let them work for you.

[Robert Penta]: And that would be an easy way to do it.

[Robert Penta]: Remember, this republic company is here for 10 years, and you've got no control over it.

[Robert Penta]: But the one thing you have control over is the people who signed off on that contract, and they have a right to go there and negotiate.

[Robert Penta]: And when my opposition turn around and put that out there, and that's one thing I would be supportive of, that senior citizens of this city park for nothing in the city of Medford.

[Robert Penta]: They don't deserve to pay.

[Robert Penta]: When I mention my wife Susan, you have to understand something.

[Robert Penta]: As much as a novice she is, she's been an educator for 23 years as a retired school teacher.

[Robert Penta]: So she knows what English, the language is all about.

[Robert Penta]: Sometimes when I talk too fast, I say the wrong words.

[Robert Penta]: It just doesn't come out right.

[Robert Penta]: And she says, you can't do that.

[Robert Penta]: You can't say that.

[Robert Penta]: But I am blessed.

[Robert Penta]: You know, Paul sort of like hit it on the head.

[Robert Penta]: I've been blessed with two women in my life and two families in my life.

[Robert Penta]: I am a very lucky man.

[Robert Penta]: I am very thankful.

[Robert Penta]: I didn't lose an election.

[Robert Penta]: You know what I won?

[Robert Penta]: I won the people of the city of Medford who believed in Bob Penta because I believe in you folks.

[Robert Penta]: And with that being said, I want to conclude by saying the following.

[Robert Penta]: My friend, Jimmy DeVito, you'll understand this.

[Robert Penta]: In 1942, it was General Douglas MacArthur who had to leave the Philippine Islands because at the Battle of Bataan, they got beaten up pretty bad.

[Robert Penta]: And he was supposed to be taking a submarine to leave the islands, because eventually he had to get to Australia.

[Robert Penta]: But he decided not to take that.

[Robert Penta]: He decided to take a PT boat and go up in the middle of the night to beat the Japanese at that point in time.

[Robert Penta]: And unfortunately, they ran into inclement weather on the whole nine yards.

[Robert Penta]: So as a result of that, he was one of the two days in the water.

[Robert Penta]: He was in open water.

[Robert Penta]: But he was very lucky, because there was no Japanese boat that saw him traversing that water, getting to where he had to go to, in Mindanao.

[Robert Penta]: Two days later, when he finally landed there, he made a very famous speech.

[Robert Penta]: And when he made that speech, it was in Melbourne, Australia.

[Robert Penta]: And this is what he said.

[Robert Penta]: This is his declaratory lines.

[Robert Penta]: He says, I came through, and I shall return.

[Robert Penta]: I took those lines and he says, how can I make that work for me tonight?

[Robert Penta]: So this is what I said.

[Robert Penta]: With that said, and with a Penta on the city ballots for the past 38 years, stay tuned.

[Robert Penta]: And while there may be a Penta in a pause mode, there will be a Penta to be continued in our days ahead.

[Robert Penta]: I thank you, my family, my friends, and even those folks who don't like me or didn't vote for me, because you know why?

[Robert Penta]: You expressed your opinion, and I'm okay with that.

[Robert Penta]: And for all those who've supported me in my positions through the years, and may our loving and forgiving God bless all of us, and may God bless us all as he sees fit.

[Robert Penta]: Bon attab.

[Robert Penta]: Thank you.

[Robert Penta]: I would be absolutely remiss if I didn't say this, because the highest thing on my scale of friendship is loyalty, and I forgot to say it.

[Robert Penta]: There's one person, and I will embarrass him, he's right over there, that guy right there, Michael Marks, from the day that I announced.

[Robert Penta]: From the day that I announced, no questions asked, he stepped up, came forward,

[Robert Penta]: over and beyond my friends, my new extended family of friends, but for an elected official to put his neck on the line, no questions asked, no wanting for anything, that to me is what it's all about.

[Robert Penta]: These are my friends, you are my friends, and God bless you all.

[Robert Penta]: Thank you.

[Robert Penta]: I would be absolutely remiss.

[Robert Penta]: My daughter, Kim.

[Robert Penta]: My son-in-law, Patrick.

[Robert Penta]: Aaron, my extended daughter.

[Robert Penta]: Aaron.

[Robert Penta]: As I said earlier this evening in some of my remarks, one of the things that

[Robert Penta]: seems to have been a concern during this past campaign was the parking in the square.

[Robert Penta]: But the incoming administration over and beyond the August questionnaire that was sent out and then the commitment that was made during this past campaign and one of the debates indicated that the administration would move for a senior citizen discount with Republic.

[Robert Penta]: So I would request that the council go on record to show the support for that as it relates to

[Robert Penta]: that for which had come up as a campaign issue and a commitment made by the incoming administration.

[Robert Penta]: Roll call vote, Mr. President.

[Robert Penta]: Mr. President, I would stick to the resolution.

[Robert Penta]: It's a separate itemized issue.

[Robert Penta]: It has makes no difference as it relates to what is going to be going forward with Louise Miller or anything else.

[Robert Penta]: It's a, it's an item that was used as a campaign issue.

[Robert Penta]: It was an item that was voted upon.

[Robert Penta]: It was an item that was campaigned on and it was an item committed upon by the incoming administration.

[Robert Penta]: So being isolated as it is and following forward with that, Mr. President, I think it would be a good way.

[Robert Penta]: and some good strength to have the incoming administration realize that the City Council supports that resolution.

[Robert Penta]: Mr. President, unfortunately at this time of the year, individuals, some individuals get recognized for whatever their contributions might be, but there is a whole host of community folks, businesses,

[Robert Penta]: and individuals who contribute all during the year for the purposes of helping those who are in need.

[Robert Penta]: For example, you have one of the banks in the square, without mentioning them, has an annual thing for Toys for Tots.

[Robert Penta]: You have the Medford Fire Department, who has an ongoing Christmas season situation.

[Robert Penta]: But you have individual people who are philanthropic unto their own right, and they don't want any recognition at all, they just do it.

[Robert Penta]: So, it doesn't make any difference whether you're a private business, a union, an individual, whatever it might be.

[Robert Penta]: These people, to some degree, if they're watching, should know that their contributions are recognized and appreciated, and as a result of that, it's our little way of saying thank you to them for being supportive for people in need when not asked to do so.

[Robert Penta]: No, it happened to come up in conversation, but the fact of the matter is in this recent monthly December bill,

[Robert Penta]: from Comcast, it'll show that it's going from $3.25 to $5.

[Robert Penta]: Now that's an increase of $1.75 a month.

[Robert Penta]: The city is presently sitting on over $450,000 of PEG access money, cable access monies, and as a result of that, still having no public access television here in the city of Medford.

[Robert Penta]: And the city's use of those monies to pay for salaries up at the high school.

[Robert Penta]: I think it's incumbent upon the incoming city council to make a demand

[Robert Penta]: from the incoming administration, whether, in fact, they are going to have cable, public access, TV3, whatever it might be.

[Robert Penta]: And there might be a twist to that, because I think if we have all been watching what's on the news lately, there's a movement afoot between Channel 7 to possibly take over, that for which Comcast has right now, which is Nessun, and I forget the other one, and WHCH.

[Robert Penta]: And with that being said, there is a possibility, if in fact this merger were to go through, and I think it would be the second highest, a multi-billion dollar merger, what could possibly happen as a movement, because if NBC does buy out the franchise, Anson, that they're looking to buy out, they could possibly retrieve the cable location of TV3 that we presently have.

[Robert Penta]: and put it in a different spot.

[Robert Penta]: That's okay, too.

[Robert Penta]: But in the contract, on page five, it says the following, PEG's access channels, any licensee-owned channels made available by the licensee in the situation as Comcast and provided for use for the presentations of PEG access programming.

[Robert Penta]: So if, in fact, if you read the contract and if you follow what's going on in the news, that if, in fact, this were to take place, there's a possibility of one or two things that ANSEN, WHCH,

[Robert Penta]: could probably be bought out by NBC, and so wouldn't be Channel 6.

[Robert Penta]: It's a side issue as it relates to the main subject matter, which is public access television, but I really think you two guys coming on as new councilors, you really have to understand that if we're going to allow public access here in the city of Medford, it needs to be worked on.

[Robert Penta]: And now, having a $1.75 increase per month on a cable access bill that people would be paying each and every month, that's approximately $60 a year,

[Robert Penta]: That's a lot of money to people, you know, you take that it's another $60 and the Community Preservation Act It's another minimum of $165 as a rate increase.

[Robert Penta]: It's another 7% that's going to be taking place on your water and sewer tax bills coming out So it is going to have an effect and I I would suggest mr. President this Medford City Council go into some kind of remedial

[Robert Penta]: a discussion as it relates to, you know, what's going on, not only with the rate increase, but, you know, how and why the city can collect this money, charge up to $5, and still not allow cable access television to go forward.

[Robert Penta]: You may want to bring the city solicitor on board on this one here to find out if, in fact, with the great increase, can they still allow, can they still continue to allow not having public access, whether it be on Channel 3 or any other channel.

[Robert Penta]: There's a value also there, too, Mr. President, of I think it's $454 or $455 million is if WHTH goes off the year, which is sort of like a sweet pot of the deal to make this thing more attractive.

[Robert Penta]: But I think the city needs to get itself involved, especially because of public access.

[Robert Penta]: The first answer is that the $450,000 that's sitting there is that's for the PEG access money.

[Robert Penta]: So if, in fact, we had a public access studio, that money would go there.

[Robert Penta]: That only represents 2 percent.

[Robert Penta]: That's 3 percent.

[Robert Penta]: The other 2 percent goes into the general fund, and that money is being paid for employees up at the high school, which is a real question mark because there are some questions as to whether that's even legal or not.

[Robert Penta]: So 1 percent goes to the fire, 1 percent to the police, and 1 percent goes to public access.

[Robert Penta]: That's the PEG money.

[Robert Penta]: Mr. President, most recently in a newspaper story published by the local press on December 17th, superintendent Belson was quoted as saying that the district has saved money in multiple areas.

[Robert Penta]: So far this year, he said, it is also possible that the position will be filled by an employee who already works for this city.

[Robert Penta]: The position he's making reference to is the new public relations potential position that the school department is now being considering.

[Robert Penta]: But I'm more concerned about his first line basically saying the district has saved money in multiple areas so far this year.

[Robert Penta]: I think it would be important for the school committee as well as the city council to get a review back as to just what are those multiple areas.

[Robert Penta]: Also, I would just like to conclude by saying the following, whether it be this or anything else.

[Robert Penta]: We have asked for numerous occasions, and the council in the past has voted for it.

[Robert Penta]: It's never taken place.

[Robert Penta]: So maybe this new school administration will take place.

[Robert Penta]: But at a minimum, the city council and the school committee should meet at least twice a year for the purposes of reviewing their financial wherewithals.

[Robert Penta]: Because this is kind of like a little bit disturbing, that if, in fact, we have money in multiple areas, when you have teachers there that are begging in time for school supplies, we're looking for special ed teachers, we're looking for teacher assistants in some of the schools,

[Robert Penta]: And we're having all kinds of areas here, and whether you're for or against hiring a person at $85,000 a year to be a public relations person.

[Robert Penta]: I think the first thing that needs to be considered is the teacher in the classroom, the needs of the teacher in the classroom, and the students that they have to take care of.

[Robert Penta]: So I think Mr. Belson owes it to the entire community of Medford, the PTOs, the PTAs, and everything else involved, that if you have multiple areas for which the school committee should be apprised of, and if they were doing their homework, they would know where these areas and how much money there is.

[Robert Penta]: That would demand a report back to the city council.

[Robert Penta]: So I would move, Mr. President, on a roll call vote to the superintendent report back into what areas that money's coming from.

[Robert Penta]: And if it's not going to affect those areas that the money's coming out of, then what's the purpose of taking the money out?

[Robert Penta]: Why aren't you using that money to fill the positions in that area?

[Robert Penta]: And then my amendment too.

[Robert Penta]: Right.

[Robert Penta]: And the folks were very appreciative of the fact.

[Robert Penta]: And as a result of that, I think we're all appreciative of the fact.

[Robert Penta]: And it would be nice to have the chief of police down here to also make public commendation recommendations as it relates to their activity.

[Robert Penta]: So on that, I move, Mr. President.

[Robert Penta]: I'd like to be invited when they come down for that one, okay?

[Robert Penta]: This recognition tonight is for a gentleman and his wife, Henry and Evelyn.

[Robert Penta]: They're like out in the community, there are a lot of silent people that do things on behalf of other folks, not looking for any recognition, not looking for any prestige, just letting folks

[Robert Penta]: know that there are other people out there to help them.

[Robert Penta]: And since I've gotten to know Henry and Elephant, they're very quiet people.

[Robert Penta]: They're not looking for much praise.

[Robert Penta]: They're not looking for anything that basically says, hey, look at me, look what I did.

[Robert Penta]: But they fortunately got recognized this past November by ARC, a nationally recognized organization.

[Robert Penta]: group of individuals, an association for whatever the reason my name might be.

[Robert Penta]: And they go out there and they help out folks who are intellectually and physically disabled.

[Robert Penta]: And it's not just in the city of Medford, it's in other and surrounding communities.

[Robert Penta]: So it gives me great pleasure, it gives me great pleasure to make this proclamation be read publicly.

[Robert Penta]: And it goes as a presentation from the Medford City Council to Henry and Evelyn Milleran.

[Robert Penta]: in recognition for your continued support within the disability community in Medford and its surrounding communities.

[Robert Penta]: Your efforts were most recently recognized at the November meeting of ARC, a nationally recognized organization that deals with the intellectual and physical disabilities of those less fortunate.

[Robert Penta]: The Medford City Council extends its deepest appreciation and gratitude for your efforts in improving the quality of life for the citizenry of Medford and all those that you have helped out.

[Robert Penta]: I'd like to have the both of you come up.

[Robert Penta]: Andrea and Evelyn, please.

[Robert Penta]: And the interesting component about these two, they're husband and wife.

[Robert Penta]: And so not only do they do their husband and wife team, they are a husband and wife team for these intellectual and physical disabilities.

[Robert Penta]: And that's a great compliment to the both of you.

[Robert Penta]: Thank you very much.

[Robert Penta]: Mr. President, and for those who might be watching and are interested in our public safety and our Medford Police Department, most recently there was an incident, a public health incident that took place in the Medford Police Department building.

[Robert Penta]: And unfortunately it was a backup and it was a sewage backup into the building, which has caused a huge contamination of probably the basement area where the cells are downstairs and a whole host of other things.

[Robert Penta]: This city council has been advocating for the past two years that their first priority would be for a new police station.

[Robert Penta]: I in my campaign for mayor advocated that a police station would be my top priority on there as well.

[Robert Penta]: What I don't understand and what I don't see is the unfortunate need that what our method police officers go through male and female on a daily basis is not being recognized and has not been recognized for the past 28 years.

[Robert Penta]: The unfortunate part is simply this.

[Robert Penta]: We need a new method police station, and we need to have our public safety be brought up to par.

[Robert Penta]: We're down by at least a minimum of 10 police officers, and that's rank and file.

[Robert Penta]: That's not management or captains or lieutenants.

[Robert Penta]: That's just rank and file patrolmen.

[Robert Penta]: You know, there's a new administration coming on board, and I would hope that they're not looked at, the police department with John Desai, because maybe they didn't take the positive position in coming out and endorsing that particular person.

[Robert Penta]: But the unfortunate part is, that should not be used against them.

[Robert Penta]: Our public safety right now is at an all-time low.

[Robert Penta]: Our police cruises are at an all-time low.

[Robert Penta]: The building itself, the evidence room, and everything else that surrounds the Medford Police Department on a daily basis is at an all-time low.

[Robert Penta]: It needs to be addressed now.

[Robert Penta]: It cannot wait.

[Robert Penta]: Public safety in our community cannot be put on hold, and it should not be put on hold.

[Robert Penta]: And I would hope that anyone who might be watching, and anyone who has an interest in public safety,

[Robert Penta]: And anyone who really believes that our Medford Police Department deserves better, because that's what our taxes are paying for, now is the time to come forward.

[Robert Penta]: You have a new administration coming on.

[Robert Penta]: You have two new Councilors coming on.

[Robert Penta]: The commitment has to be made.

[Robert Penta]: The finances has to be looked out for and sought out.

[Robert Penta]: And they can be.

[Robert Penta]: Malden is a perfect example.

[Robert Penta]: They're building a brand new police station.

[Robert Penta]: They already have $9 million of the $18 million they've already secured in grants.

[Robert Penta]: Medford cannot be put on hold any longer.

[Robert Penta]: in regards to its police department.

[Robert Penta]: And with that being said, Mr. President, I would hope that this city council and the incoming city council holds new administration's feet to the fire to build that brand-new police station in behalf of not only the citizens of this community, but because of the public safety that is necessary and it's demanding right now on a daily basis.

[Robert Penta]: All you have to do is talk to the police officers, talk to the chief of police,

[Robert Penta]: and ask them what they think should be done as compared to what is being done.

[Robert Penta]: I thank you.

[Robert Penta]: Mr. President, since 2013 until now, December of 2015, it's been approximately 2 years.

[Robert Penta]: And during that period of time, the city of Medford has intentionally, the city administration has intentionally taken ratepayers' money from Comcast and subsequently, since Verizon has come on board,

[Robert Penta]: for what they call public access TV here in the city of Medford.

[Robert Penta]: As of today, there is approximately $400,000, $450,000 sitting in the city coffers downstairs for public access television.

[Robert Penta]: Public access television for which the mayor and its current administration has intentionally not allowed here in the city of Medford.

[Robert Penta]: And who's at the loss of that?

[Robert Penta]: And that's the cable TV subscribers.

[Robert Penta]: Whether you agree or disagree with anyone running for office, no candidate

[Robert Penta]: for this past election had the opportunity to be on public access, to have their position stated, accepted, rejected, or even looked at.

[Robert Penta]: No citizen of this community has had the opportunity to have their shows relative to sports, family events, or anything that might be educational, historical, to be put on public access television.

[Robert Penta]: During the past two years, what the mayor did is he implemented a three-member committee person, three-member person committee, for the purposes of reviewing public access here in the city of Medford.

[Robert Penta]: Coming up with a concocted story,

[Robert Penta]: that at some point in time, on or before Memorial Day of 2015, we would have something ongoing.

[Robert Penta]: And we don't.

[Robert Penta]: This is now December 2015, almost seven months later.

[Robert Penta]: And the money just keeps coming out of your cable bill each and every month from Verizon and Comcast.

[Robert Penta]: We had a public access meeting here for contract renewal with Comcast here in the city of Medford.

[Robert Penta]: It was another 10-year deal.

[Robert Penta]: And no one, not one person from the city administration,

[Robert Penta]: Not one person showed up to defend and argue on behalf of Comcast customers.

[Robert Penta]: I, along with nine other citizens, were here to do that.

[Robert Penta]: And this isn't because we're for or against.

[Robert Penta]: It's a 10-year contract.

[Robert Penta]: And in today's day and age, 10-year contracts are basically unheard of, especially when technology is so far advanced and it's ever-changing.

[Robert Penta]: From California all the way to Massachusetts, there's a combination of maybe even a collage

[Robert Penta]: between Verizon and Comcast technicians working together, sharing their jobs together as they traverse across the country.

[Robert Penta]: And yes, there is a movement out there that maybe public access is not the way to go because between Amazon and all these other technological programs that are out there between a combination of streaming or buying on Netflix or whatever it might be, the idea is out there that the city of Medford is not having it.

[Robert Penta]: With a proposal now that seems to be languishing,

[Robert Penta]: of possibly putting it up in the vocational school, a place that would serve no purpose, especially in the winter months that we have right now.

[Robert Penta]: It's dark out.

[Robert Penta]: The bus route would stop the person getting off at the bottom of the hill.

[Robert Penta]: You would have to walk up to the top of the hill.

[Robert Penta]: God knows where you would have to go into the building to get in.

[Robert Penta]: It does not serve a purpose because all this type of information on public access needs to be located in a centrally located place.

[Robert Penta]: And when you have something that's centrally located, it would bring more people.

[Robert Penta]: City of Reading, Town of Reading, perfect example.

[Robert Penta]: Not only do they have it in the downtown area, they have it on every Saturday morning at 11 o'clock.

[Robert Penta]: It's open to the public, coffee and donuts.

[Robert Penta]: People can come in.

[Robert Penta]: They show you how to make your own program.

[Robert Penta]: They lease out, rent out their equipment.

[Robert Penta]: They show you how to use the equipment.

[Robert Penta]: They show you how to make your own programs.

[Robert Penta]: There was nowhere near $450,000 sitting in the coffers downstairs.

[Robert Penta]: That's what the people have paid for.

[Robert Penta]: And as far as that goes, Mr. President, I leave my comments as they are.

[Robert Penta]: Mr. President, one of the key components of public access television is taking place here tonight.

[Robert Penta]: We're allowing peoplenot allowing, this is the People's Forum.

[Robert Penta]: They're having the opportunity to come up and speak for whatever their positions might be.

[Robert Penta]: But in June of 2014, a federal judge by the name of James O. Browning made a very distinct comment as it relates to people who have the opportunity to come up and speak and to give their opinions.

[Robert Penta]: And what that federal judge did to this particular city was to punish, and I won't say use the word punish, was to admonish them for not allowing criticism to be made at a podium.

[Robert Penta]: Because as he said, criticism at a podium is an unconstitutional burden on free speech.

[Robert Penta]: So if somebody wants to come here, or a council wants to compliment, commend, or whatever it might be, or somebody wants to go to that podium and speak in such a manner, so be it.

[Robert Penta]: But criticism of any commentary is just as much important or is just as much a part of free speech.

[Robert Penta]: And just as Browning indicated, and he said, limits can be placed on time and topic, but not on a speaker's opinion.

[Robert Penta]: And whatever the speaker feels he'd like to say, within reason, as long as it's not abusive, and it's his opinion, it needs to be allowed.

[Robert Penta]: He wrote an 89-page decision, and I'm waiting for that.

[Robert Penta]: I asked for the 89-page decision on that, because that's a huge issue right now.

[Robert Penta]: Freedom of speech, and allowing freedom of speech, and inclusive of freedom of speech, if there's a criticism included in there, and they're saying it, and it's done in fair commentary, it should not be excluded.

[Robert Penta]: and it should not be cut off.

[Robert Penta]: So I believe it's monumental.

[Robert Penta]: It goes back to June of 2014.

[Robert Penta]: It's a federal district court justice making his opinion.

[Robert Penta]: And that's the second time within the year 2014 that two federal judges came out

[Robert Penta]: and made this commentary as it relates to free speech.

[Robert Penta]: And those who might want to critique or be critical of somebody speaking or whatever the commentary might be, as he said, quote, it's an unconstitutional burden on free speech by disallowing someone to voice their opinion, be it in a critique manner.

[Robert Penta]: Thank you.

[Robert Penta]: The case was very succinct and it was not allowing people to speak.

[Robert Penta]: The council

[Robert Penta]: in its wisdom, decided council president, for whatever the reasons might be, did not allow people to make negative comments, to say anything negative at council meetings.

[Robert Penta]: And that, in and of itself, was an unconstitutional burden on free speech.

[Robert Penta]: Whether it was a council rule or the actions that were taking place, it found itself all the way to the Supreme Court.

[Robert Penta]: Strike that, the Federal District Court, by Justice Browning.

[Robert Penta]: So I guess a word to the wise is sufficient.

[Robert Penta]: And the ruling is very succinct.

[Robert Penta]: It isn't like you're wiping it out.

[Robert Penta]: You're just keeping all things being equal.

[Robert Penta]: You know, a few years back, it was Councilor Marks to his credit.

[Robert Penta]: The only one that didn't vote

[Robert Penta]: to take the money out of the Water and Sewer account because the mayor underfunded the budget by a million one.

[Robert Penta]: But we're sitting on nine and a half million dollars.

[Robert Penta]: Why is the city so reluctant to try out something and see where it takes us?

[Robert Penta]: The law says, unless you have something that's ready to go in a ready-made project within 90 days, or there's a surplus remaining that goes back to the rate payers.

[Robert Penta]: Now, this has been going on for a few years.

[Robert Penta]: $7 million and $36 million.

[Robert Penta]: $7 million, $36,000, leaving you with a balance.

[Robert Penta]: I'm going to vote.

[Robert Penta]: that this not go through, that this money come out of the Water and Soil Enterprise account, period.

[Robert Penta]: The rate payers should not have to pay for this.

[Robert Penta]: Let the city figure out where they went wrong and if they have to make an adjustment.

[Robert Penta]: Because it's bad enough that they've been taxed for everything in this community from A to Z. And I just don't think it's fair, especially knowing that you have a remaining balance of $7 million and there is not one project sitting in front of us right now that has a demand of any kind of money.

[Robert Penta]: that the water and sewer account has for a balance.

[Robert Penta]: That's number one.

[Robert Penta]: Number two, I can see leaving maybe two or $3 million in that account in case an emergency takes place.

[Robert Penta]: We've had no discussion from the city engineer, the building department or the highway department, public works department regarding a project that the city needs to undertake right now or it's going to be undertaking.

[Robert Penta]: All we know right now is that there is this kind of a surplus sitting there.

[Robert Penta]: It's unfair.

[Robert Penta]: I don't think that the rate payers should have their money that they've paid for

[Robert Penta]: now be charged again.

[Robert Penta]: I think that money should stay in this account and the city and the city engineer and the new administration should figure out what all the INI and the water leaks and the things that need to be corrected here in this community.

[Robert Penta]: They better get on their duff real quick because this is what the administration has been talking about, whether it was myself or the incoming person, you know, this city needs to have a lot of reconstruction in this community as it relates to their water and sewer, their INI and their street and their side construction projects.

[Robert Penta]: So,

[Robert Penta]: Take this out of this account and transfer it over to pay a debt that belongs with the city.

[Robert Penta]: If they mismanaged and miscalculated, don't blame the taxpayer.

[Robert Penta]: They've been blamed enough for what goes on in this community.

[Robert Penta]: I'm going to move, Mr. President, that the money come out of the retained earnings of the Water and Sewer account and not be transferred.

[Robert Penta]: Mr. President, I agree with Councilor Marks and my colleague Councilor Lungo-Koehn.

[Robert Penta]: The interesting part, you were at that meeting,

[Robert Penta]: Louise, as it relates to the conservation.

[Robert Penta]: shall be automatically laid on the table for one week when such action is requested by any councillor.

[Robert Penta]: But I'll get to that later on.

[Robert Penta]: It's still part of the comparison.

[Robert Penta]: You know, when we came on board at the beginning of the year, we were asked to give what our priorities were.

[Robert Penta]: And I believe the police department and police station was our number one priority.

[Robert Penta]: And unfortunately, it hasn't found itself anywhere in any of the mayor's agendas.

[Robert Penta]: Now, the police station would derive an extreme benefit for our community.

[Robert Penta]: It would make us go forward.

[Robert Penta]: not only socially, but as a community going forward with tomorrow's technology, and it would also give a presence of community policing.

[Robert Penta]: And that's something I think a lot of the people asking for, more police officers, more patrolmen, more visibility.

[Robert Penta]: And if you give them a better place to work out of, then I think that would go a long way.

[Robert Penta]: You know, we paid in excess, I think, of $78,000

[Robert Penta]: when we received the feasibility study from the police department and the fire department on May 5th of this year.

[Robert Penta]: And unfortunately for the police department, they didn't get anything out of it.

[Robert Penta]: Fire department did, but the police department didn't.

[Robert Penta]: And once again, I don't know, maybe it's just the mayor, he doesn't have it on his radar screen, but public safety, I believe is the first of priorities here of any of all the councilors.

[Robert Penta]: Some of the things that Mr. Mayor, that would be beneficial, not only for our community,

[Robert Penta]: is the council has supported, in each and every calendar budget, the recycling of two new cruises each and every year.

[Robert Penta]: And that would go a long way, once again, to add to the police officers on duty, driving their cruises, letting them know that the city is thinking about them, and they don't have to drive in a car that has about 140,000 miles on it, and they don't know if it's gonna make it or not.

[Robert Penta]: I think it was Councilor Marks, three years ago,

[Robert Penta]: came up with the idea of why can't we have a special truck enforcement unit?

[Robert Penta]: It's a great idea.

[Robert Penta]: What's wrong with training one or two people to be involved with truck enforcement for that particular purpose?

[Robert Penta]: Because I think we can go down any one of these streets in any one of these days, and we see the amount of trucks that travel down High Street, Main Street, or the major streets here in the city of Medford.

[Robert Penta]: That would go a long way.

[Robert Penta]: In our public safety issue regarding lighting, all the squares are just dimly lit.

[Robert Penta]: And that in and of itself is an invitation

[Robert Penta]: for some type of crime, whatever the crime might be.

[Robert Penta]: You get Route 16, the parking lot behind St.

[Robert Penta]: Joe's.

[Robert Penta]: This will probably be the 14th time that we've discussed this, and still no lighting.

[Robert Penta]: We've had situations there where a lady called up and she was afraid to get into a car because of people there, and also in a separate situation where a drug transaction was reported.

[Robert Penta]: Also right here in Medford Square, the Route 16 overpass, underpass on Route 93,

[Robert Penta]: has no lights.

[Robert Penta]: Riverside Avenue, go underneath the overpass there, still no lights.

[Robert Penta]: We have asked for the issue of public safety, timely street swiping.

[Robert Penta]: We've also asked for our crosswalk painting.

[Robert Penta]: You're lucky if you see that once a year.

[Robert Penta]: These aren't huge cost items.

[Robert Penta]: These are items that are readily available within our budget.

[Robert Penta]: Now we've talked about police cameras and high visibility locations.

[Robert Penta]: Were it not for the business merchant that owned a store on the corner of George and Winthrop Street a few years, a couple of years back, how they caught the guy that assaulted the young lady from Tufts University.

[Robert Penta]: And as a result of that, Mr. President, we all know that the cameras are beneficial.

[Robert Penta]: We have $8,893 in our linkage account for where they could buy a few cameras.

[Robert Penta]: But if you really want to get into it, we have $6,400,000 in our free cash account.

[Robert Penta]: So I don't think there should be any reason why we can't go out there and buy any cameras.

[Robert Penta]: A bonus to our people that work.

[Robert Penta]: We can review the one day a week and swap day reward.

[Robert Penta]: And that would be for those officers with a perfect attendance for six months.

[Robert Penta]: Something different, something creative for the police officers.

[Robert Penta]: rather than the annual, it's on a six month basis, and that might work out, it's a tryout, it's something to think about.

[Robert Penta]: I think we should also think about revisiting the idea of having retired police personnel be part of the parking enforcement proposal here in the city of Medford.

[Robert Penta]: Because that in and of itself, that in and of itself would bring a big luxury, not only to the people here in this community, but I think to the business people who would have a better idea of knowing

[Robert Penta]: when and how to tag certain folks.

[Robert Penta]: Because we really don't know what this out-of-state company from Tennessee is going to be like.

[Robert Penta]: They could just be, I don't know, they're going to start at 7 o'clock in the morning to 7 at night.

[Robert Penta]: It doesn't make any sense.

[Robert Penta]: Boston doesn't even start till 8 o'clock in the morning.

[Robert Penta]: We have a civil defense system that needs to be addressed.

[Robert Penta]: Is it in limbo?

[Robert Penta]: Is it going to be used?

[Robert Penta]: If not,

[Robert Penta]: We've talked about a snow emergency system, and we haven't heard anything back on that.

[Robert Penta]: And I think we're all aware of the fact that a snow emergency system of some type needs to be in place.

[Robert Penta]: And taking some of these issues and putting them on the left, then I go to the right, and I look at this idea of this new proposal that, if you agree or disagree, the mayor signed into effect apparently today regarding this Tennessee firm Republic.

[Robert Penta]: regarding a traffic enforcement program that's going to be six days a week from 7 in the morning to 7 p.m.

[Robert Penta]: at night.

[Robert Penta]: There'll be no free parking on the streets.

[Robert Penta]: According to the mayor's commentary, there's going to be two 30-minute parking spots in each one of the squares, and there'll be four paid single-space meter spots in each of the four square districts.

[Robert Penta]: Other than that, there'll be kiosks allotted.

[Robert Penta]: It's kind of like interesting because if you look at the commentary made by the director from the Medford Chamber of Commerce, Mr. White, he indicated that he was hoping that he would have an opportunity with its members to sit down and discuss this.

[Robert Penta]: And he also made reference to the fact that each and every one of the squares have unique positions, unique concerns as it relates to businesses and how they might be affected.

[Robert Penta]: How the mayor came up to this resolution and signing, I don't know.

[Robert Penta]: But it's kind of like unfair because we were in that meeting on September 10th, and we were told that he would get back to us.

[Robert Penta]: He never honored that.

[Robert Penta]: We were told also that the concerns that would be brought up would be addressed and to have an idea.

[Robert Penta]: I don't know, and we don't really know what part of the business community, what businesses are going to be exempt from not having a meter or a kiosk anywhere in that particular area.

[Robert Penta]: And some of the samples that I just talked about still have yet to be addressed.

[Robert Penta]: But the mayor thinks it's more important to go forward with a parking enforcement program, strike that, a paid to park program with enforcement that's only going to bring in $300,000 the first year and $700,000 from the second to the ninth year, it's the 10th year.

[Robert Penta]: May sound like a lot of money, but my feeling personally would have been, had the city decided to go forward after that meeting on the 10th, having an opportunity to listen to the folks within our community, listen to the business in the community, all four areas of this community, rather than have one size fits all, which includes Medford Square, in the press release as outlined tonight at 510,

[Robert Penta]: He signed the contract.

[Robert Penta]: He says he got a letter from the chamber.

[Robert Penta]: and they needed to be heard, and they weren't heard, and the mayor decides to have one size fits all, I don't think that's what you call a happy resolution, especially to the business people and to the taxpayers of this community.

[Robert Penta]: You know, the fact of the matter is this.

[Robert Penta]: We're getting rid of people who don't live in the community, who were parking at spots all day long, and they haven't been tagged.

[Robert Penta]: And this has been going on for the entire years of the administration of this city, this mayor.

[Robert Penta]: And now what we're going to be doing is tagging, if not towing, and telling our own taxpayers in this community, you people are going to have to start paying.

[Robert Penta]: So,

[Robert Penta]: put $300,000 this first year out of the box, compare everything to what the police department needs to keep our community safe and protected.

[Robert Penta]: right there in and of itself tends to indicate a lack of professionalism in the letter going out.

[Robert Penta]: The Water and Soil Commission has appeared before the council and to explain this new idea of tiered rates and commercial rates or whatever it might be and however it's going to take place.

[Robert Penta]: And that passed.

[Robert Penta]: Unfortunately, the mayor sends an answer back and says it's the council's purview.

[Robert Penta]: I mean, it's the Water and Soil Commission's purview to make that decision, number one.

[Robert Penta]: And number two, this is a matter that involves the entire city for the purposes of being involved and getting involved.

[Robert Penta]: The council has asked on numerous occasions for the Water and Soil Commission.

[Robert Penta]: I personally have met with the chairman of the Water and Soil Commission.

[Robert Penta]: I asked him to come here.

[Robert Penta]: We're still waiting for him to come here.

[Robert Penta]: The mayor has never offered a public meeting or a hearing on this particular increase.

[Robert Penta]: So there is a complete lack of public education on this increase.

[Robert Penta]: And as a result of this, we have problems here.

[Robert Penta]: Look at your bill that just came out, and it talks about

[Robert Penta]: The rates only apply to homes with up to four families and residential condo buildings.

[Robert Penta]: And then it gives you a 0 to 800 as a base.

[Robert Penta]: And I don't know where they got that 800 as being the base.

[Robert Penta]: Again, no determination from that.

[Robert Penta]: And then from 800 cubic feet to 1,600 feet, you get to another rate.

[Robert Penta]: And it goes on.

[Robert Penta]: And after that, there's a third rate.

[Robert Penta]: So as a residential owner, you could have up to three types of rates in your particular house.

[Robert Penta]: And then it goes down further to indicate

[Robert Penta]: Every other person or every other type of an account will be charged 0.138.

[Robert Penta]: Now, does that mean that that's going to be a commercial rate?

[Robert Penta]: I thought we were led to believe that there was going to be allegedly a commercial rate, which would be different than the regular rate.

[Robert Penta]: But if you go back to the first paragraph, they talk about they're adopting this in response to Chapter 165, Section 2B.

[Robert Penta]: And 165, Section 2B is very explicit

[Robert Penta]: where it talks about, shall institute water charges and fees that incorporate a base rate for all, provided, which means other than or maybe, that said base rate shall be increased at an increased block rate to fairly reflect the resource demand and consumption of high volume uses of water.

[Robert Penta]: Now think about high volume uses of water.

[Robert Penta]: If you live in a three-family house, for the example that they use, you are a single person on the first floor.

[Robert Penta]: There is two, three people on the third floor, five or six people on the third floor.

[Robert Penta]: And they use the example you used, 2,100 units of water.

[Robert Penta]: Well, they're going to take the 2,100 units of water, divide it by three, and everybody's going to be tagged with 700 units of water to be charged.

[Robert Penta]: That doesn't make any sense at all, number one, because number one,

[Robert Penta]: Not everybody has a meter in their apartment.

[Robert Penta]: And if it's a single meter that's going to cover the whole house, some houses are like that.

[Robert Penta]: I mean, how do you distribute that?

[Robert Penta]: I mean, where they come up with this, I have absolutely no idea.

[Robert Penta]: And this is what prompted probably eight or nine of my 13 calls that I've already received so far in this.

[Robert Penta]: How do they make this type of a determination?

[Robert Penta]: But more importantly, personally, I think this is the mayor's way of retaliating against the council.

[Robert Penta]: because we didn't give him his $600,000 in the budget.

[Robert Penta]: Bad enough we didn't give him his parking garage.

[Robert Penta]: And as a result of that, this rate increase not only will pick up the $600,000, it'll probably exceed that.

[Robert Penta]: Absolutely, absolutely not fair.

[Robert Penta]: It is not right.

[Robert Penta]: At the present time, people should be aware of the fact, at the present time, in our water and sewer retained earnings account, we have $8,400,000 as of today.

[Robert Penta]: $8,400,000.

[Robert Penta]: We would have $9,600,000 if we didn't take a million two a few years ago to take the mayor out of his deficit hole because he couldn't balance the budget.

[Robert Penta]: But with that being said, $8 million, that's a lot of money.

[Robert Penta]: And we're talking about rate payers having to be charged right now.

[Robert Penta]: There is nothing in this letter that would even give you an assumption

[Robert Penta]: that it's going to take place next year, or the next billing cycle.

[Robert Penta]: They just jam it in the letter, and there it is in your new bill.

[Robert Penta]: Now, I went back, and to my knowledge, the last time in billing cycles in 2006, as compared to the bills that we have right now, the 2006 bill, sixth bill, tells you

[Robert Penta]: The cost, it breaks it down for water and sewer, the cost.

[Robert Penta]: Your water and sewer cost is not broken down in these blue bills that we've been getting for a long period of time.

[Robert Penta]: And as a result of that, I'm going to suggest in part, Mr. President, that the city's water and sewer department and the city of Medford building department reinstitute the prior building process that not only showed the prior readings, the present readings, the usage,

[Robert Penta]: but the rates for water and the rates for sewer per 100 cubic feet.

[Robert Penta]: So the people have an informed, knowledgeable bill, rather than getting a dollar amount and trying to figure out the hocus pocus that's going on.

[Robert Penta]: Baseline water usage of 800, where do they get that?

[Robert Penta]: I have absolutely no idea who determined, and they don't even tell you where it came from.

[Robert Penta]: The bill, as I said before, it doesn't ID the water and sewer rates.

[Robert Penta]: But back and prior to 2006, it did.

[Robert Penta]: It gives you everything that you would want to know to try to figure out your bill.

[Robert Penta]: Now, your old rate consumption as compared to your new rate consumption, that's another thing that's not on here.

[Robert Penta]: Because all they're doing and they're telling you on the blue bill, it's just telling you what you had last time, what the reading was, and the amount.

[Robert Penta]: And once again, what's water, what's sewer, I don't know.

[Robert Penta]: I think what really needs to be done on this particular issue is two things.

[Robert Penta]: You can't send out bills to people and just tell them it becomes effective now.

[Robert Penta]: That's number one.

[Robert Penta]: Number two, you don't send out a letter that's undated.

[Robert Penta]: Number three, you don't turn around and tell, for an example, a three-family house, you're going to split it between the three floors, and everyone's going to pay the same amount on a per-unit charge.

[Robert Penta]: You don't do that.

[Robert Penta]: Second of all, there's nothing on this bill

[Robert Penta]: on this letter that talks about a commercial rate.

[Robert Penta]: And I think Councilor Marks, is he here?

[Robert Penta]: I think there was an issue relative to a commercial rate before.

[Robert Penta]: You know, where are we going with that?

[Robert Penta]: It says all other rates will be 0.1381.

[Robert Penta]: And that will be the same rate as someone who goes from the 800 to the 1600 level in a residential home.

[Robert Penta]: I said it before and I'll say it again.

[Robert Penta]: If families are going to be penalized because they have

[Robert Penta]: children or mothers and fathers or seniors living with them.

[Robert Penta]: That's not fair.

[Robert Penta]: It's absolutely not fair.

[Robert Penta]: And as the law says, the resources should go on the demand and the consumption of high volume uses of water.

[Robert Penta]: A residential home, maybe just over this 800 level or whatever it might be, those aren't high uses of water.

[Robert Penta]: That's baseline wherever they got it.

[Robert Penta]: Maybe the zero to 800.

[Robert Penta]: should be maybe the $0 to $1,200 or $1,400, and then change it after that.

[Robert Penta]: Because I don't think it's bad enough rate payers, you're hitting them with a federal tax.

[Robert Penta]: You hit them with your state tax.

[Robert Penta]: You hit them with a meals tax.

[Robert Penta]: You're hitting them with a gas tax.

[Robert Penta]: You hit them with your real estate tax.

[Robert Penta]: And now you want to raise their water and sewer tax with an $8.4 million surplus sitting in a kitty.

[Robert Penta]: It's wrong.

[Robert Penta]: This is not what the council asked for.

[Robert Penta]: I believe this is the mayor's

[Robert Penta]: way of getting back at the council because $600,000 was taken out of the budget for which the council voted for to knock off the 10% rate increase?

[Robert Penta]: Well, this rate increase is definitely going to exceed the 10% that the mayor was losing, or the $600,000.

[Robert Penta]: And who's going to pay for it?

[Robert Penta]: It's the everyday person.

[Robert Penta]: I would strongly suggest, Mr. President, once again, as we did in August, if the mayor says this is within the purview of the council,

[Robert Penta]: Then let it be in the purview and strike that respectfully request that the Board of Commissioners appear before the Medford City Council for the purposes of explaining not only the letter, but the rates as to where we're going.

[Robert Penta]: And also respectfully request that they change their billing process to accurately show the rate for water, the rate for sewer, where it's going, and the amount.

[Robert Penta]: Now with that being said, Mr. President,

[Robert Penta]: I can't find anyone, and I'm still waiting.

[Robert Penta]: I had a long talk today with Mr. Remsburg, who was the chief legal counsel for the MWRA.

[Robert Penta]: And in my conversation with him, which represented the same type of conversation I had with him in August of this past year, we're back to the same issue for which I believe we're on the same page.

[Robert Penta]: The bigger users, the demand for bigger users and demand for more consumption and high volume of users of water should be the first ones, according to this chapter of the law, to be paid.

[Robert Penta]: It says, all municipalities and water districts within the jurisdiction of the MWRA, but not including community service by the Connecticut Valley Aqueduct, shall institute water charges and fees that incorporate a base rate for all users.

[Robert Penta]: Okay?

[Robert Penta]: They're saying 800 is the base rate.

[Robert Penta]: But it says, provided that said base rate shall be increased at an increasing block rate to fairly recollect

[Robert Penta]: the resources, demand, and consumption of high-volume uses of water.

[Robert Penta]: If somebody is 801, is they going to be tagged as a high-volume use of water?

[Robert Penta]: Because that person at 801, which could be residential, is going to be tagged at the same amount that everyone else is going to be tagged that's not residential.

[Robert Penta]: And you're going to have to assume it's commercial, because they don't say it.

[Robert Penta]: But what is it?

[Robert Penta]: Everybody else but residential.

[Robert Penta]: It's got to be commercial.

[Robert Penta]: So with that being said,

[Robert Penta]: That's three strikes since the summer of this year.

[Robert Penta]: How much more is it that the people of this community want to take?

[Robert Penta]: But the insanity of saying that a three-family or a two-family or a four-family house is going to be divided by the amount of units, and that's what they're going to pay.

[Robert Penta]: They have no right saying that.

[Robert Penta]: They have no right doing that.

[Robert Penta]: While he may be running off a string of resolutions, we had asked for a public hearing and a public meeting on this and for whatever

[Robert Penta]: the Water and Soil Commissioners might have done or made the determination.

[Robert Penta]: The council has been asked to be apprised, and they've been asked to appear before here, and they never have.

[Robert Penta]: So 800 getting to the baseline, how did you get to it?

[Robert Penta]: Where did you come up with that number?

[Robert Penta]: Because if you look at a lot of the residential homes, they're going to be between 800 and that 1,600 mark.

[Robert Penta]: So by going over by one cubic feet, you're going to be putting that residential homeowner, who might have two or three kids or taking care of a senior citizen, paying a higher rate.

[Robert Penta]: And that's where I think the discussion needs to take place.

[Robert Penta]: I'm not denying the fact that the more you use, the more you should pay.

[Robert Penta]: But this is a big gap from $800 to $800 to $1,600.

[Robert Penta]: And if you are just a little bit over that, you're going to be saddled with that additional thing.

[Robert Penta]: Yeah, clarification.

[Robert Penta]: Okay.

[Robert Penta]: So, I mean, we have two separate entities here running around.

[Robert Penta]: We have no transmission, no broadcasting coming forward.

[Robert Penta]: And even if they had to get sued, who cares about getting sued?

[Robert Penta]: That's number one.

[Robert Penta]: Number two, why wasn't that thought out ahead of time

[Robert Penta]: to know that cable access could not go there.

[Robert Penta]: And if that's the case, what is, if any, legal ramifications that might be involved?

[Robert Penta]: accessed in and out of one place.

[Robert Penta]: On motion to Councilor Penta, Vice President Del Russo.

[Robert Penta]: While you might be autonomous legally,

[Robert Penta]: You are taking ratepayers' money for which the mayor of this community overrides your corporation, because he administers Channel 3.

[Robert Penta]: There's nothing to be confused.

[Robert Penta]: Don't play the game tonight, Frank.

[Robert Penta]: You're paying people at work that have no job to go to.

[Robert Penta]: No, let me give you the history.

[Robert Penta]: The history is this, Frank.

[Robert Penta]: Frank, Frank, the history is this.

[Robert Penta]: He hasn't earned my respect, Mr. President.
